script_text: <speak> Leo's dog, Biscuit, loved to play fetch. Every afternoon, Leo would throw a tennis ball across the yard. Biscuit always brought it back, wagging his tail.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What did Leo throw?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A stick? <break time='400ms'/> A frisbee? <break time='400ms'/> A tennis ball? <break time='400ms'/> or A bone? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the second sentence again ‚Äî what did Leo throw across the yard?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> On the first day of second grade, Emma felt nervous. She didn't know anyone in her new class. At lunch, a girl named Priya sat next to her and said, "Want to share my crackers?"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why was Emma nervous?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She didn't know anyone? <break time='400ms'/> She was late? <break time='400ms'/> She lost her backpack? <break time='400ms'/> or She forgot her lunch? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look at the second sentence ‚Äî what made Emma feel nervous?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Grandpa and Tomas built a birdhouse together. They used wood, nails, and bright blue paint. They hung it on the oak tree in the backyard.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Who helped Tomas build the birdhouse?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> His grandpa? <break time='400ms'/> His mom? <break time='400ms'/> His teacher? <break time='400ms'/> or His friend? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the very first sentence ‚Äî who was with Tomas?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> It was raining hard, so the soccer game was canceled. Ava was disappointed. Her dad said, "Let's play board games instead!" They played three rounds of her favorite game.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>When was the soccer game canceled?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> When it was sunny? <break time='400ms'/> When it was raining hard? <break time='400ms'/> When it was windy? <break time='400ms'/> or When it was snowing? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The very first sentence tells you why ‚Äî and when!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The ant worked all summer storing food. The grasshopper played and sang. When winter came, the ant had plenty to eat, but the grasshopper had nothing.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the lesson of this story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It's good to plan ahead? <break time='400ms'/> Singing is fun? <break time='400ms'/> Ants are better than grasshoppers? <break time='400ms'/> or Winter is cold? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the ant did differently ‚Äî why was the ant okay in winter?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The tortoise and the hare had a race. The hare ran fast but stopped to nap. The tortoise kept going slowly and steadily. The tortoise crossed the finish line first.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the moral of this story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Running fast always wins? <break time='400ms'/> Slow and steady wins the race? <break time='400ms'/> Napping is healthy? <break time='400ms'/> or Turtles are faster than rabbits? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The tortoise never stopped. The hare did. Who won?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Rosa wanted the biggest piece of cake. She pushed ahead of everyone in line. Her friends were upset and didn't want to sit with her. Rosa wished she had waited her turn.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the lesson of this story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Birthdays are fun? <break time='400ms'/> Cake is delicious? <break time='400ms'/> Being patient and fair matters? <break time='400ms'/> or Lines are boring? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What happened when Rosa pushed ahead? How did her friends feel?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A lion was caught in a hunter's net. A tiny mouse chewed through the ropes and set the lion free. The lion had once let the mouse go instead of eating it.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the message of this story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Hunters are mean? <break time='400ms'/> Mice like cheese? <break time='400ms'/> Even small friends can be a big help? <break time='400ms'/> or Lions are scary? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Who saved the lion? Was the mouse big or small?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ben bragged that he was the best speller in class. During the spelling bee, he didn't study and missed an easy word. His friend Kai, who had practiced every night, won.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the central message?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Spelling is hard? <break time='400ms'/> Kai got lucky? <break time='400ms'/> Ben is a bad speller? <break time='400ms'/> or Hard work beats bragging? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Compare what Ben did and what Kai did to prepare.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Lily's sandcastle was knocked down by a big wave. She felt sad at first, but then she smiled and said, "I'll build an even bigger one!"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Lily respond to the challenge?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She decided to build a bigger one? <break time='400ms'/> She cried and gave up? <break time='400ms'/> She yelled at the wave? <break time='400ms'/> or She went home? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did Lily say after she smiled?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> During the talent show, Jake forgot the words to his song. His face turned red. Then he took a deep breath and started over from the beginning.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Jake handle forgetting the words?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He started crying? <break time='400ms'/> He took a deep breath and started over? <break time='400ms'/> He ran off the stage? <break time='400ms'/> or He asked the teacher for help? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did Jake do after his face turned red?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> When the power went out during the storm, Maya was scared. Her mom lit candles and they told funny stories. Soon Maya was laughing instead of being afraid.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Maya's feelings change?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She stayed scared the whole time? <break time='400ms'/> She fell asleep? <break time='400ms'/> She went from scared to laughing? <break time='400ms'/> or She got angry? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! How did Maya feel at the start? How did she feel at the end?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Sam's best friend moved to a different city. Sam was really sad. He asked his mom if they could write letters to each other. Now Sam and his friend are pen pals.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Sam respond when his friend moved away?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He forgot about his friend? <break time='400ms'/> He found a way to stay in touch? <break time='400ms'/> He moved too? <break time='400ms'/> or He was angry at his friend? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What idea did Sam have to solve the problem?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Nora's team lost the championship game. Some kids were upset, but Nora high-fived every player and said, "We played our best. I'm proud of us."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Nora's response tell us about her?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She didn't care about winning? <break time='400ms'/> She is a good sport? <break time='400ms'/> She was secretly angry? <break time='400ms'/> or She doesn't like soccer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what Nora did and said after losing. Was she kind?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The rain came down, drip, drip, drop. It wouldn't quit, it wouldn't stop!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What do the words drip, drip, drop help you imagine?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The sound of rain falling? <break time='400ms'/> A sunny day? <break time='400ms'/> Wind blowing? <break time='400ms'/> or A loud thunderstorm? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'drip, drip, drop' out loud ‚Äî what does it sound like?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Swoosh went the broom across the floor. Swish, swish, swoosh ‚Äî it swept some more!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The words swoosh and swish help the reader ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Hear the sound of sweeping? <break time='400ms'/> Learn how to clean? <break time='400ms'/> See the color of the broom? <break time='400ms'/> or Know what time it is? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! These words copy the sounds a broom makes!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Silly Sally sat on a seal, singing songs by the sea.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What makes this sentence fun to say?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Many words start with the same sound? <break time='400ms'/> It has lots of periods? <break time='400ms'/> It rhymes at the end? <break time='400ms'/> or It has big words? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look at the first letter of most words. What do you notice?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The leaves danced in the wind, twirling and spinning to the ground.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word danced makes the leaves seem ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Wet and cold? <break time='400ms'/> Lively and playful? <break time='400ms'/> Heavy and slow? <break time='400ms'/> or Scary and dark? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! When you dance, how do you move? Happy or sad?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Tick-tock, tick-tock, the clock on the wall. Tick-tock, tick-tock, it counts for us all.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why does the author repeat tick-tock?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To make it scary? <break time='400ms'/> Because they forgot what to write? <break time='400ms'/> To make the poem longer? <break time='400ms'/> or To copy the sound and rhythm of a clock? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What sound does a clock make? Does the poem sound like that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Once upon a time, a girl named Zara found a magic key. She used it to open a secret door in her attic. Behind the door was a land of talking animals. After many adventures, Zara returned home and locked the door.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which part is the beginning of the story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She locked the door? <break time='400ms'/> Zara found a magic key? <break time='400ms'/> The land of talking animals? <break time='400ms'/> or Zara returned home? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The beginning introduces who the story is about and what starts the adventure.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a story, what does the ending usually do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Wrap up the story and solve the problem? <break time='400ms'/> Describe the setting? <break time='400ms'/> Introduce new characters? <break time='400ms'/> or Start a new problem? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what happens at the very end of most stories you've read.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Devin wanted to win the art contest. He painted every day after school. His painting of a sunset won first place!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the problem at the beginning?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Devin wanted to win the contest? <break time='400ms'/> Devin went to school? <break time='400ms'/> Devin won a prize? <break time='400ms'/> or Devin painted a sunset? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The beginning tells you what the character wants or needs.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which part of a story introduces the characters and setting?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The title? <break time='400ms'/> The beginning? <break time='400ms'/> The ending? <break time='400ms'/> or The middle? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Where do you first meet the characters and learn where the story takes place?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Mia lost her puppy in the park. She looked everywhere. Finally, she heard barking behind the slide and found her puppy playing with another dog.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does the ending conclude the action?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Mia loses her puppy? <break time='400ms'/> Mia looks everywhere? <break time='400ms'/> Mia goes to the park? <break time='400ms'/> or Mia finds her puppy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The ending solves the problem. What was Mia's problem?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ana thought the roller coaster was amazing and wanted to ride again. Her brother Carlos shook his head and said, "No way, that was too scary!"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How are Ana's and Carlos's feelings different?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ana loved it but Carlos was scared? <break time='400ms'/> Both were scared? <break time='400ms'/> Carlos loved it but Ana didn't? <break time='400ms'/> or Both wanted to ride again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did Ana say? What did Carlos say? Are they the same?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Mom said, "We should get a cat." Dad said, "I think a dog would be better." Jayden said, "Can we get both?"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Who has a different point of view from Mom?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both Dad and Jayden? <break time='400ms'/> Only Dad? <break time='400ms'/> Nobody? <break time='400ms'/> or Only Jayden? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Mom wants a cat. Does Dad agree? Does Jayden agree exactly?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The farmer was happy when it rained because his crops needed water. The children were sad because they couldn't play outside.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why do the farmer and the children feel differently about the rain?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The farmer likes being wet? <break time='400ms'/> Rain helps the farmer's crops but stops the children's play? <break time='400ms'/> They live in different places? <break time='400ms'/> or The children don't like water? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about why rain is good for the farmer and not fun for the kids.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ella wanted to stay up late to watch a movie. Her mom said it was a school night and bedtime was 8 o'clock.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How is Ella's point of view different from her mom's?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ella wants to sleep but mom says no? <break time='400ms'/> They both agree on bedtime? <break time='400ms'/> Ella wants to stay up but mom wants her to go to bed? <break time='400ms'/> or Mom wants to watch the movie too? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What does Ella want? What does Mom want? Are they the same?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In the story, the Big Bad Wolf said, "I just wanted to borrow some sugar!" The Three Little Pigs said, "He tried to blow our houses down!"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How are the points of view different?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The wolf says he was friendly but the pigs say he was dangerous? <break time='400ms'/> They agree on what happened? <break time='400ms'/> The pigs like the wolf? <break time='400ms'/> or The wolf admits he was bad? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The wolf and the pigs tell different stories about the same event!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If a story says Tomas felt happy and the picture shows him with a big smile and jumping, what do the words AND picture together tell you?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tomas is pretending? <break time='400ms'/> Tomas is a little happy? <break time='400ms'/> Tomas is very happy? <break time='400ms'/> or Tomas is sick? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words say happy. The picture shows a big smile AND jumping. That's MORE than just happy!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A story's words say: "It was a dark night." The picture shows rain, lightning, and bent trees. What can you tell about the setting?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It's snowing? <break time='400ms'/> It's a calm evening? <break time='400ms'/> It's a sunny morning? <break time='400ms'/> or There's a big storm? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words say dark. The picture adds rain, lightning, and bent trees. Put them together!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why are illustrations important in a story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They replace the words? <break time='400ms'/> They are only for decoration? <break time='400ms'/> They help you understand the characters and setting better? <break time='400ms'/> or They make the book heavier? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what you learn from looking at pictures in a story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A story says "Maya walked into the room." The picture shows Maya with wide eyes, an open mouth, and a room full of balloons and presents. What is probably happening?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Maya is sad? <break time='400ms'/> Maya is going to bed? <break time='400ms'/> Maya is at a surprise party? <break time='400ms'/> or Maya is at school? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words just say she walked in. But the PICTURE shows you what she found!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The text says: "The old man sat on the bench." The picture shows him feeding pigeons with a gentle smile and a cane beside him. What do you learn from the picture that the words don't tell you?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He's feeding pigeons and seems kind? <break time='400ms'/> He's an old man? <break time='400ms'/> He's outside? <break time='400ms'/> or He's sitting on a bench? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words say he sat. What EXTRA information does the picture give?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Two versions of Cinderella both have a girl who goes to a ball. In one version, a fairy godmother helps her. In the other, magic fish help her. What is the SAME in both?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A girl goes to a ball? <break time='400ms'/> The magic fish? <break time='400ms'/> The prince's name? <break time='400ms'/> or The fairy godmother? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for what happens in BOTH versions.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When you compare two versions of the same story, you look for things that are ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both the same AND different? <break time='400ms'/> Only different? <break time='400ms'/> Only the same? <break time='400ms'/> or Not in either story? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Comparing means finding what's alike. Contrasting means finding what's different. You do both!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In an American version of a folktale, the hero is a cowboy. In a Japanese version, the hero is a samurai. Both heroes save their village. What is DIFFERENT?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The heroes are brave? <break time='400ms'/> Both save a village? <break time='400ms'/> The stories have a happy ending? <break time='400ms'/> or The type of hero? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What is the same? They both save a village. What changes between the two stories?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Story A: A boy finds a golden egg laid by a goose. Story B: A girl finds a golden seed that grows into a money tree. How are these stories similar?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both are about boys? <break time='400ms'/> Both have a goose? <break time='400ms'/> Both have a tree? <break time='400ms'/> or Both characters find something magical and valuable? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A golden egg and a golden seed are both magical treasures. What's the bigger idea they share?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why might the same story be told differently in different cultures?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> People in other places don't like stories? <break time='400ms'/> The authors copied each other? <break time='400ms'/> One version is right and the other is wrong? <break time='400ms'/> or Each culture adds its own setting, characters, and traditions? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about how a story told in Japan might have different details than one told in Mexico.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The wind howled through the trees as Sophie clutched her flashlight. She had promised to walk to the mailbox alone, and she wasn't going to break her promise. With each step, the shadows seemed to dance around her.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How is Sophie feeling?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bored and tired? <break time='400ms'/> Brave but a little scared? <break time='400ms'/> Angry at someone? <break time='400ms'/> or Excited and happy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She made a promise and kept going ‚Äî that's brave. But the howling wind and shadows suggest she's also a little scared.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Jackson's painting looked nothing like the sunset he was trying to copy. He almost crumpled it up, but then his art teacher said, "Art doesn't have to be perfect ‚Äî it just has to be yours."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What did Jackson learn?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Art should be a perfect copy? <break time='400ms'/> His teacher is mean? <break time='400ms'/> He should stop painting? <break time='400ms'/> or His own style matters? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did the teacher tell him? Does art have to be perfect?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Every day, the old lighthouse keeper climbed 137 steps to light the lamp. Ships depend on me, he would say. Even in the worst storms, the light always shone.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What word BEST describes the lighthouse keeper?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Dedicated? <break time='400ms'/> Lazy? <break time='400ms'/> Silly? <break time='400ms'/> or Confused? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! He climbed 137 steps every day, even in bad storms. That takes commitment!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The squirrel buried an acorn in the fall. By spring, a tiny green sprout poked through the soil. Years later, it became the tallest oak in the forest.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is this story mainly about?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Small things can grow into something big? <break time='400ms'/> Forests have lots of trees? <break time='400ms'/> Spring is the best season? <break time='400ms'/> or Squirrels are forgetful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the journey ‚Äî from a tiny acorn to the tallest oak tree.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "I'll never make friends here," whispered Amir on his first day at the new school. By the end of the week, he had joined the soccer team and made three new friends.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What happened that Amir did NOT expect?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He went to a new school? <break time='400ms'/> He felt nervous? <break time='400ms'/> He played soccer? <break time='400ms'/> or He made friends quickly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did Amir say at the beginning? Did that come true?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Honeybees live in hives. A hive can have up to 60,000 bees! The queen bee lays all the eggs, and worker bees collect nectar from flowers.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the queen bee do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Guards the hive? <break time='400ms'/> Lays all the eggs? <break time='400ms'/> Collects nectar? <break time='400ms'/> or Builds the hive? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the last sentence ‚Äî what is the queen bee's special job?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Firefighters wear special gear to stay safe. Their helmets protect their heads. Their thick coats keep them safe from fire and heat.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why do firefighters wear thick coats?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To keep safe from fire and heat? <break time='400ms'/> Because they like heavy clothes? <break time='400ms'/> To look cool? <break time='400ms'/> or To stay warm in winter? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The last sentence tells you exactly why!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> George Washington Carver was a scientist who studied peanuts. He found over 300 uses for peanuts, including making soap, ink, and dye.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many uses did Carver find for peanuts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 3,000? <break time='400ms'/> 300? <break time='400ms'/> 30? <break time='400ms'/> or 100? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for the number in the second sentence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Sea turtles travel thousands of miles through the ocean. They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Where do sea turtles lay their eggs?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In the deep ocean? <break time='400ms'/> On any beach? <break time='400ms'/> On the beach where they were born? <break time='400ms'/> or In a nest in a tree? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the second sentence ‚Äî which beach do they go back to?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In 1969, astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the Moon for the first time. Millions of people watched on television.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>When did astronauts first walk on the Moon?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 1979? <break time='400ms'/> 1959? <break time='400ms'/> 1989? <break time='400ms'/> or 1969? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The year is right at the beginning of the passage.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Dogs make great pets. They are loyal and friendly. Many dogs can be trained to do tricks. Some dogs even help people who are blind.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main topic?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Why dogs make great pets? <break time='400ms'/> How to train pets? <break time='400ms'/> Cats? <break time='400ms'/> or Animals at the zoo? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence tells you the main idea. The rest gives examples!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Paragraph 1: Apples come in many colors ‚Äî red, green, and yellow. Paragraph 2: Apples are good for you because they have vitamins and fiber.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is Paragraph 2 mostly about?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The colors of apples? <break time='400ms'/> How to grow apples? <break time='400ms'/> Why apples are healthy? <break time='400ms'/> or Apple pie recipes? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Paragraph 2 talks about vitamins and fiber. That means it's about health!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A passage has three paragraphs. One is about where penguins live. One is about what they eat. One is about how they raise their babies. What is the MAIN topic of the whole passage?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Penguin food? <break time='400ms'/> Antarctic weather? <break time='400ms'/> Baby animals? <break time='400ms'/> or All about penguins? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Each paragraph covers a different detail about the same animal.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Water can be a solid, a liquid, or a gas. Ice is solid water. Steam is water as a gas. The water you drink is a liquid.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main topic?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How to make steam? <break time='400ms'/> Ice is cold? <break time='400ms'/> Drinking water? <break time='400ms'/> or The three forms of water? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence tells you the big idea ‚Äî water has three forms.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How can you find the main topic of a passage with many paragraphs?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Count the sentences? <break time='400ms'/> Read only the first word? <break time='400ms'/> Look at the pictures only? <break time='400ms'/> or Think about what ALL the paragraphs are about together? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The main topic is the big idea that connects all the paragraphs.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> First, the caterpillar eats lots of leaves. Then, it makes a chrysalis. Finally, it comes out as a butterfly.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What happens AFTER the caterpillar makes a chrysalis?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It makes another chrysalis? <break time='400ms'/> It eats more leaves? <break time='400ms'/> It goes to sleep forever? <break time='400ms'/> or It becomes a butterfly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Follow the steps: eat ‚Üí chrysalis ‚Üí what comes last?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The sun heats the ocean water. The water evaporates into the air. Clouds form. Then rain falls back to the ground.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What causes clouds to form?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The moon? <break time='400ms'/> Water evaporating into the air? <break time='400ms'/> Rain falling? <break time='400ms'/> or Wind blowing? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What happens right BEFORE clouds form?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In 1903, the Wright Brothers flew the first airplane. Their flight lasted only 12 seconds. Today, planes can fly across the whole world.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How are the events connected?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The Wright Brothers' invention led to modern airplanes? <break time='400ms'/> Modern planes were invented first? <break time='400ms'/> They are not related? <break time='400ms'/> or The Wright Brothers flew across the world? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first event (1903 flight) started something big. What came from it?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> To make a peanut butter sandwich: First, get two slices of bread. Next, spread peanut butter on one slice. Then, put the other slice on top.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What do you do right AFTER spreading peanut butter?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Put the other slice on top? <break time='400ms'/> Get the bread? <break time='400ms'/> Eat the sandwich? <break time='400ms'/> or Open the jar? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Follow the steps in order ‚Äî what comes right after spreading?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> When bees visit flowers, pollen sticks to their legs. They carry the pollen to other flowers. This helps new plants grow.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does pollen getting on bees connect to new plants growing?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Plants grow on their own? <break time='400ms'/> Pollen makes bees fly faster? <break time='400ms'/> Bees carry pollen to other flowers, which helps plants grow? <break time='400ms'/> or Bees eat the plants? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Follow the chain: pollen on legs ‚Üí carried to flowers ‚Üí what happens?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Nocturnal animals are active at night. Owls, bats, and raccoons are nocturnal.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does nocturnal mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Active at night? <break time='400ms'/> Very fast? <break time='400ms'/> Living in water? <break time='400ms'/> or Active during the day? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sentence right after 'nocturnal' tells you ‚Äî active at what time?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A habitat is the natural home of an animal or plant. A frog's habitat is near ponds and streams.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is a habitat?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of food? <break time='400ms'/> A kind of weather? <break time='400ms'/> A natural home? <break time='400ms'/> or A baby animal? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence gives you the definition!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Mammals are warm-blooded animals that have fur or hair. Dogs, cats, and humans are all mammals.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Based on the text, what makes an animal a mammal?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It can fly? <break time='400ms'/> It lays eggs? <break time='400ms'/> It lives in water? <break time='400ms'/> or It is warm-blooded with fur or hair? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence describes exactly what a mammal is.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The ancient Egyptians built enormous pyramids. These huge stone structures still stand today.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does enormous mean in this sentence?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very colorful? <break time='400ms'/> Very old? <break time='400ms'/> Very small? <break time='400ms'/> or Very huge? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The next sentence calls them 'huge stone structures.' That's a clue!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Plants need nutrients from the soil to grow. Nutrients are like food for plants ‚Äî they give plants energy and help them stay healthy.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What are nutrients?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of soil? <break time='400ms'/> Sunlight? <break time='400ms'/> Water? <break time='400ms'/> or Food-like substances that help plants grow? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The second sentence explains it ‚Äî nutrients are like food for plants!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You want to find the meaning of the word ecosystem in a science book. Where should you look?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The title page? <break time='400ms'/> The glossary? <break time='400ms'/> The table of contents? <break time='400ms'/> or The index? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A glossary is like a mini-dictionary at the back of a book!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the purpose of a heading in a nonfiction text?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To tell you what that section is about? <break time='400ms'/> To end the chapter? <break time='400ms'/> To list the author's name? <break time='400ms'/> or To decorate the page? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Headings are like little titles for each section.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You want to know which page has information about dolphins. Which text feature should you use?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bold print? <break time='400ms'/> The glossary? <break time='400ms'/> The index? <break time='400ms'/> or A caption? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An index lists topics alphabetically with their page numbers!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a nonfiction book, some words are in bold print. Why?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To make the page look pretty? <break time='400ms'/> To show important or new vocabulary words? <break time='400ms'/> Because the author likes those words? <break time='400ms'/> or Because they are misspelled? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Bold words stand out because they're important for the reader to know!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A small sentence under a photograph that explains what's in the picture is called a ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Caption? <break time='400ms'/> Title? <break time='400ms'/> Heading? <break time='400ms'/> or Paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think of the little labels under photos in books and magazines.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Brush your teeth twice a day. Use toothpaste with fluoride. Visit the dentist every six months.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the author's purpose?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To tell a funny story? <break time='400ms'/> To explain how to take care of your teeth? <break time='400ms'/> To describe a toothbrush? <break time='400ms'/> or To sell toothpaste? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author is giving you instructions about dental health.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The blue whale is the largest animal ever to live on Earth. It can be over 100 feet long and weigh as much as 200 tons.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author wrote this to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tell a story about a whale? <break time='400ms'/> Convince you to visit the ocean? <break time='400ms'/> Inform you about blue whales? <break time='400ms'/> or Make you laugh? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Is the author giving you facts or telling a story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Everyone should recycle! When we recycle, we save trees and keep trash out of the ocean. Please recycle your cans, bottles, and paper.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author's main purpose is to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Describe what recycling looks like? <break time='400ms'/> Persuade you to recycle? <break time='400ms'/> Teach you how paper is made? <break time='400ms'/> or Entertain you with a story? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Words like 'should' and 'please' are clues that the author wants you to DO something.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A book that teaches you about different types of clouds was written to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Persuade? <break time='400ms'/> Scare? <break time='400ms'/> Entertain? <break time='400ms'/> or Inform? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If a book teaches you facts, the purpose is to inform!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Butterflies have four stages in their life: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, and butterfly. Each stage is an important part of their life cycle.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What question is the author trying to answer?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Why are butterflies colorful?? <break time='400ms'/> Where do butterflies live?? <break time='400ms'/> What are the stages of a butterfly's life?? <break time='400ms'/> or How fast can butterflies fly?? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The passage lists stages. What question does that answer?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A science book has a paragraph about the parts of a plant. Next to it is a diagram with labels pointing to the roots, stem, leaves, and flower. How does the diagram help?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It makes the page look nice? <break time='400ms'/> It replaces the paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> It shows you exactly where each plant part is? <break time='400ms'/> or It shows a different topic? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The paragraph tells you ABOUT the parts. The diagram shows you WHERE they are.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A text about weather says: "A thermometer measures temperature." Below it is a picture of a thermometer showing 32¬∞F. What does the picture add?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It shows what a thermometer looks like and how to read it? <break time='400ms'/> It replaces the need to read? <break time='400ms'/> Nothing new? <break time='400ms'/> or It tells you about rain? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words explain what it does. The picture shows what it LOOKS like and a reading.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why would an author include a map in a book about animals around the world?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To show where different animals live? <break time='400ms'/> To make the book longer? <break time='400ms'/> To show what animals eat? <break time='400ms'/> or To teach you to draw? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Maps show locations. If the book is about animals around the world, what would a map show?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A book about healthy eating includes a picture of a food plate divided into sections: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, and dairy. This image helps the reader ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> See how much of each food group to eat? <break time='400ms'/> Learn to draw plates? <break time='400ms'/> Know what to buy at the store? <break time='400ms'/> or Cook a meal? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The plate shows sections of different sizes ‚Äî what does that tell you?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which type of image would BEST help explain how a bicycle works?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A photo of someone walking? <break time='400ms'/> A labeled diagram showing bicycle parts? <break time='400ms'/> A painting of a bicycle race? <break time='400ms'/> or A photograph of a sunset? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! To explain HOW something works, you need to see the parts and what they do.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Recess is important for kids. It gives them time to exercise. It also helps them focus better in class.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What reason does the author give for why recess helps in class?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Kids like to play? <break time='400ms'/> It helps them focus better? <break time='400ms'/> It makes school longer? <break time='400ms'/> or Teachers need a break? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the last sentence ‚Äî what does recess help kids do in class?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Everyone should drink more water. Water keeps your body healthy. It helps your brain work better. It also gives you energy.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many reasons does the author give for drinking water?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 2? <break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 1? <break time='400ms'/> or 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Count each benefit: healthy body, better brain, and energy. That's three!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Helmets should be worn when riding a bike. They protect your head if you fall. Studies show helmets reduce head injuries by 85%.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What supports the author's point that helmets are important?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They reduce head injuries by 85%? <break time='400ms'/> They come in many colors? <break time='400ms'/> Everyone has a bike? <break time='400ms'/> or Helmets look cool? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author uses a fact with a number to support the point. Which sentence has the number?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When an author writes because in a sentence, what usually follows?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A reason that supports their point? <break time='400ms'/> The end of the paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> A question? <break time='400ms'/> or A new topic? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Because' is a signal word that introduces WHY something is true.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Schools should have gardens. Gardens teach kids about science. They also help kids eat healthier because kids are more likely to eat vegetables they grew themselves.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which reason explains HOW gardens help kids eat healthier?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Kids eat vegetables they grew themselves? <break time='400ms'/> Gardens are pretty? <break time='400ms'/> Schools have space for gardens? <break time='400ms'/> or Gardens teach science? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for the sentence with 'because' ‚Äî that gives the detailed reason.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A says dogs are great pets because they are loyal. Text B says dogs are great pets because they can be trained. What do BOTH texts agree on?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Dogs are better than cats? <break time='400ms'/> Dogs can be trained? <break time='400ms'/> Dogs are great pets? <break time='400ms'/> or Dogs are loyal? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What main point do both texts share?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A about the ocean focuses on ocean animals. Text B about the ocean focuses on pollution in the ocean. How are these texts different?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Text A is fiction? <break time='400ms'/> They are about different topics? <break time='400ms'/> They say the same things? <break time='400ms'/> or They focus on different aspects of the same topic? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both texts are about the ocean, but each focuses on something different.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Text A: "Bats use sound to find food in the dark." Text B: "Bats eat insects and help farmers by keeping pests away."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Text B tell you that Text A does not?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bats are mammals? <break time='400ms'/> Bats use sound? <break time='400ms'/> Bats help farmers? <break time='400ms'/> or Bats fly at night? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read Text B ‚Äî what information is new and not in Text A?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When comparing two texts on the same topic, what should you look for?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> What information is the same and what is different? <break time='400ms'/> Which text has more pictures? <break time='400ms'/> Which text was written first? <break time='400ms'/> or Which text is longer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Comparing means finding things that are alike AND different.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Text A says: "Exercise keeps your heart healthy." Text B says: "Exercise helps you sleep better and makes your bones strong."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which benefit is mentioned in Text A but NOT Text B?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A healthy heart? <break time='400ms'/> Stronger bones? <break time='400ms'/> More energy? <break time='400ms'/> or Better sleep? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read Text A carefully ‚Äî which benefit does it mention that Text B doesn't?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Octopuses are amazing creatures. They have eight arms and three hearts. They can change color to blend in with their surroundings. Some octopuses can even open jars!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>According to the text, how many hearts does an octopus have?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Eight? <break time='400ms'/> One? <break time='400ms'/> Two? <break time='400ms'/> or Three? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The second sentence lists two number facts. Which one is about hearts?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Great Wall of China was built over many centuries to protect China from invaders. It stretches over 13,000 miles, making it the longest structure ever built by humans.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why was the Great Wall built?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To divide cities? <break time='400ms'/> For decoration? <break time='400ms'/> For tourists to visit? <break time='400ms'/> or To protect from invaders? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence explains the purpose ‚Äî to protect from what?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to power a TV for three hours. Americans throw away enough cans each year to build more than 20 Eiffel Towers.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the author trying to show with these facts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Americans watch too much TV? <break time='400ms'/> The Eiffel Tower is made of cans? <break time='400ms'/> Recycling cans saves a lot of energy? <break time='400ms'/> or TVs use too much power? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author compares cans to TV power and Eiffel Towers. Why? To show recycling matters!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Polar bears have black skin under their white fur. The white fur helps them hide in the snow. Their large paws work like snowshoes, helping them walk on ice.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What helps polar bears walk on ice?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Their sharp teeth? <break time='400ms'/> Their large paws? <break time='400ms'/> Their black skin? <break time='400ms'/> or Their white fur? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the last sentence ‚Äî what works like snowshoes?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Volcanoes form when hot melted rock called magma pushes up through the Earth's surface. When magma comes out, it's called lava. Over time, the lava cools and builds up to form the volcano's cone shape.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is magma called after it comes out of the volcano?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rock? <break time='400ms'/> Ash? <break time='400ms'/> Lava? <break time='400ms'/> or Steam? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The second sentence tells you the new name for magma once it's outside.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a long vowel sound?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cap? <break time='400ms'/> Cat? <break time='400ms'/> Can? <break time='400ms'/> or Cake? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A long vowel says its own name. Which word has the 'ay' sound?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the root word in playing?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Paying? <break time='400ms'/> Ing? <break time='400ms'/> Lay? <break time='400ms'/> or Play? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Remove the ending '-ing' ‚Äî what word is left?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has the prefix un-?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Uncle? <break time='400ms'/> Unhappy? <break time='400ms'/> Until? <break time='400ms'/> or Under? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A prefix is added to the BEGINNING of a base word. 'Un-' + 'happy' = ?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in the word pumpkin?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 1? <break time='400ms'/> 2? <break time='400ms'/> or 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it out: pump-kin. How many claps?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is spelled correctly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Because? <break time='400ms'/> Becaws? <break time='400ms'/> Becuz? <break time='400ms'/> or Becuase? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is a tricky word! Sound it out: be-cause.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a SHORT a sound?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rain? <break time='400ms'/> Bake? <break time='400ms'/> Day? <break time='400ms'/> or Map? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Short 'a' sounds like the 'a' in 'cat.' Which word has that sound?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a LONG o sound?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Home? <break time='400ms'/> Hot? <break time='400ms'/> Hop? <break time='400ms'/> or Lot? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Long 'o' says its own name, like 'oh.' Which word sounds like that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word bed has a ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Long 'a' sound? <break time='400ms'/> Long 'e' sound? <break time='400ms'/> Short 'i' sound? <break time='400ms'/> or Short 'e' sound? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'bed' out loud. Does the 'e' say its name or make a short sound?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which pair shows a short vowel word and its long vowel partner?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Dog ‚Üí dig? <break time='400ms'/> Run ‚Üí ran? <break time='400ms'/> Cat ‚Üí cut? <break time='400ms'/> or Pin ‚Üí pine? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Adding a silent 'e' at the end makes the vowel long!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word does NOT have a long vowel sound?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cube? <break time='400ms'/> Bike? <break time='400ms'/> Mule? <break time='400ms'/> or Milk? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say each word. Three have vowels that say their own name. One has a short 'i.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In the word boat, what sound does the vowel team oa make?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Short 'a'? <break time='400ms'/> Long 'o'? <break time='400ms'/> Long 'a'? <break time='400ms'/> or Short 'o'? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'boat' ‚Äî the 'oa' makes the 'oh' sound!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has the ee vowel team?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Red? <break time='400ms'/> Tree? <break time='400ms'/> Bed? <break time='400ms'/> or Ten? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for two e's side by side!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The vowel team ai in rain makes the same sound as ay in ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ant? <break time='400ms'/> Play? <break time='400ms'/> About? <break time='400ms'/> or All? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'rain' and 'play' ‚Äî do the vowels sound the same?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has the same vowel sound as seat?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Set? <break time='400ms'/> Feet? <break time='400ms'/> Fit? <break time='400ms'/> or Sat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The 'ea' in seat makes a long 'e' sound. Which other word has that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which vowel team is in the word loud?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ou? <break time='400ms'/> Oi? <break time='400ms'/> Oo? <break time='400ms'/> or Oa? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look at the middle of 'loud' ‚Äî which two vowels are together?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Break the word cupcake into two syllables:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cu-pcake? <break time='400ms'/> Cup-cake? <break time='400ms'/> C-upcake? <break time='400ms'/> or Cupc-ake? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is a compound word made of two smaller words!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word robot has two syllables. How do you break it apart?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rob-ot? <break time='400ms'/> Robo-t? <break time='400ms'/> Ro-bot? <break time='400ms'/> or R-obot? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Each syllable needs a vowel. Where's the natural break?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which two-syllable word has a long i sound?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Mitten? <break time='400ms'/> Spider? <break time='400ms'/> Kitten? <break time='400ms'/> or Rabbit? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say each word. Which one has the 'eye' sound in it?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in the word music?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 2? <break time='400ms'/> 1? <break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> or 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it: mu-sic. How many claps?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Break open into syllables:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Open? <break time='400ms'/> O-pen? <break time='400ms'/> Ope-n? <break time='400ms'/> or Op-en? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The 'o' is long and open ‚Äî it gets its own syllable!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does unkind mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Kind again? <break time='400ms'/> Not kind? <break time='400ms'/> A type of kind? <break time='400ms'/> or Very kind? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The prefix 'un-' means 'not.' So un + kind = ?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The suffix -ful in hopeful means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Before? <break time='400ms'/> Full of? <break time='400ms'/> Not? <break time='400ms'/> or Without? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:
