script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Hope + ful = full of hope!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does reread mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Read again? <break time='400ms'/> Not reading? <break time='400ms'/> Read for the first time? <break time='400ms'/> or Stop reading? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The prefix 're-' means 'again.' So re + read = ?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a suffix?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Inside? <break time='400ms'/> Slowly? <break time='400ms'/> Undo? <break time='400ms'/> or Replay? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A suffix goes at the END of a word. '-ly' is a common suffix.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If care means to look after something, what does careless mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Caring again? <break time='400ms'/> Very caring? <break time='400ms'/> Full of care? <break time='400ms'/> or Not careful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The suffix '-less' means 'without.' Without care = ?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word does NOT follow regular phonics rules?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Dog? <break time='400ms'/> Run? <break time='400ms'/> Said? <break time='400ms'/> or Cat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Try sounding it out ‚Äî does 'said' sound like it's spelled?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word have is tricky because ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The 'a' doesn't make the expected sound? <break time='400ms'/> It ends with 'e' but the 'a' is short? <break time='400ms'/> It has too many letters? <break time='400ms'/> or It has a silent 'h'? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Usually a word ending in 'e' has a long vowel. But 'have' has a short 'a'!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a silent letter?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cup? <break time='400ms'/> Stop? <break time='400ms'/> Lamp? <break time='400ms'/> or Know? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say each word. In one of them, a letter is there but you don't hear it.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In the word love, the o makes the sound of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Long 'o' (like 'bone')? <break time='400ms'/> Long 'u' (like 'cute')? <break time='400ms'/> Short 'u' (like 'cup')? <break time='400ms'/> or Short 'o' (like 'hot')? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'love' and 'cup.' The vowel sounds the same!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which of these words is a tricky sight word that doesn't follow phonics rules?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Pot? <break time='400ms'/> Big? <break time='400ms'/> The? <break time='400ms'/> or Map? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Try to sound out each word with regular rules. Which one doesn't work?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is spelled correctly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Peopel? <break time='400ms'/> People? <break time='400ms'/> Peeple? <break time='400ms'/> or Peple? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'People' is a tricky word ‚Äî the 'eo' doesn't sound like you'd expect.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Choose the correct spelling:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Friend? <break time='400ms'/> Frend? <break time='400ms'/> Freind? <break time='400ms'/> or Frind? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Remember: 'i' before 'e' in friend!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses their correctly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Their going to the park.? <break time='400ms'/> Their is a dog outside.? <break time='400ms'/> I went their yesterday.? <break time='400ms'/> or They put their books away.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Their' means 'belonging to them.' Which sentence shows something belonging to them?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Choose the correct spelling of the word that means one more time:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Agane? <break time='400ms'/> Agin? <break time='400ms'/> Again? <break time='400ms'/> or Agen? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This tricky word ends with '-ain' like 'rain.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is an irregularly spelled word you need to memorize?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Help? <break time='400ms'/> Stop? <break time='400ms'/> Because? <break time='400ms'/> or Jump? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Three of these words can be sounded out. One is tricky and needs to be memorized.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does it mean to read fluently?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reading smoothly with expression? <break time='400ms'/> Reading silently? <break time='400ms'/> Reading very fast? <break time='400ms'/> or Reading every word perfectly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Fluent reading sounds natural, like talking ‚Äî not too fast, not too slow.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When you see an exclamation mark (!) at the end of a sentence, you should read it with ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A quiet voice? <break time='400ms'/> Excitement or strong feeling? <break time='400ms'/> A question in your voice? <break time='400ms'/> or No change in voice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An exclamation mark means the sentence has strong emotion!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If you don't understand a sentence after reading it, what should you do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Read it again more carefully? <break time='400ms'/> Ask someone to read the whole book? <break time='400ms'/> Close the book? <break time='400ms'/> or Skip it and keep going? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers go back and reread to make sure they understand.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Stop!" yelled the crossing guard.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How should you read the word Stop?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very slowly? <break time='400ms'/> In a loud, firm voice? <break time='400ms'/> In a silly voice? <break time='400ms'/> or In a whisper? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The crossing guard 'yelled' ‚Äî so you should read it like a yell!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When a good reader comes to a word they don't know, they ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Use clues from the sentence to figure it out? <break time='400ms'/> Stop reading the book? <break time='400ms'/> Skip the whole page? <break time='400ms'/> or Guess randomly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The other words in the sentence can help you figure out the mystery word!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The farmer planted seeds in the spring. He watered them every day. By summer, his garden was full of tomatoes, peppers, and corn.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What grew in the farmer's garden?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tomatoes, peppers, and corn? <break time='400ms'/> Apples? <break time='400ms'/> Wheat? <break time='400ms'/> or Flowers? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the last sentence ‚Äî it lists what grew!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Before you start reading, it helps to ask yourself ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> What do I want to learn from this?? <break time='400ms'/> Who wrote this book?? <break time='400ms'/> How many pages is this?? <break time='400ms'/> or What color is the cover?? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Setting a purpose helps you focus while reading.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Dolphins are mammals, not fish. They breathe air and feed milk to their babies. Dolphins are very smart and can learn tricks.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What makes dolphins different from fish?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They have tails? <break time='400ms'/> They breathe air and feed milk to babies? <break time='400ms'/> They swim? <break time='400ms'/> or They live in the ocean? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The passage says dolphins are mammals, not fish. What makes them mammals?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ben's favorite book is about space. He reads it every week because he wants to be an astronaut someday.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why does Ben read the space book so often?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He has to for school? <break time='400ms'/> It's the only book he has? <break time='400ms'/> His mom makes him? <break time='400ms'/> or He wants to be an astronaut? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sentence after 'because' tells you the reason.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Earthworms help gardens by making tunnels in the soil. The tunnels let air and water reach plant roots.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How do earthworm tunnels help plants?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They let air and water reach the roots? <break time='400ms'/> They make the garden look nice? <break time='400ms'/> They keep bugs away? <break time='400ms'/> or They make the soil warmer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Read the second sentence ‚Äî what do the tunnels let through?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How should you read this sentence? "I can't believe we won the game!"</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In a whisper? <break time='400ms'/> Slowly and sadly? <break time='400ms'/> With excitement and energy? <break time='400ms'/> or With no expression? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The exclamation mark and 'I can't believe' show strong, happy feelings!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When you read a question aloud, your voice should ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Go up at the end? <break time='400ms'/> Stay the same? <break time='400ms'/> Get very loud? <break time='400ms'/> or Go down at the end? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Try saying 'Are you coming?' ‚Äî notice how your voice rises at the end?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A character in a story whispers, "Shhh, the baby is sleeping." How should you read this line?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In a loud voice? <break time='400ms'/> With an angry tone? <break time='400ms'/> Softly and quietly? <break time='400ms'/> or Very fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The character is whispering ‚Äî match that with your voice!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does reading at an appropriate rate mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reading so slowly that it's hard to follow? <break time='400ms'/> Reading at a comfortable speed ‚Äî not too fast, not too slow? <break time='400ms'/> Skipping every other word? <break time='400ms'/> or Reading as fast as possible? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about how you talk ‚Äî that's a good speed for reading aloud too.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How should you read this line from a character who is scared? "W-what was that noise?"</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> With a shaky, nervous voice? <break time='400ms'/> Very fast and cheerful? <break time='400ms'/> Happily and loud? <break time='400ms'/> or In a bored voice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The dashes in 'W-what' show stuttering ‚Äî the character is scared!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You read: "The dog buried a bone in the yard." But you accidentally read bone as "bun." What should you do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ask someone to read for you? <break time='400ms'/> Keep reading? <break time='400ms'/> Stop reading the book? <break time='400ms'/> or Go back and reread because 'bun' doesn't make sense? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Does 'The dog buried a bun in the yard' make sense? If not, try again!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The bird flew to its ____." Which word fits best?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Best? <break time='400ms'/> Test? <break time='400ms'/> Desk? <break time='400ms'/> or Nest? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Where do birds live? Use the rest of the sentence to decide.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is a good strategy when a sentence doesn't make sense?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reread the sentence and try the hard word again? <break time='400ms'/> Skip the whole page? <break time='400ms'/> Read faster? <break time='400ms'/> or Close the book? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers slow down and try again when something doesn't sound right.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The cat climbed up the tall ___." Which word makes the most sense?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tree? <break time='400ms'/> Cloud? <break time='400ms'/> Book? <break time='400ms'/> or Spoon? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What tall thing can a cat climb?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You read a word as horse but the sentence says: "The family lives in a big _____ on the hill." What should the word probably be?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Hope? <break time='400ms'/> House? <break time='400ms'/> Hose? <break time='400ms'/> or Horse? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A family lives in a ____. Which word makes sense?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The tiny kitten was so small it fit in my hand."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does tiny mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very big? <break time='400ms'/> Very loud? <break time='400ms'/> Very small? <break time='400ms'/> or Very fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sentence says the kitten was so small it fit in a hand. 'Tiny' means the same as 'small.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The word bat can mean a flying animal OR a stick used in baseball. In this sentence, what does bat mean?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Jake swung the bat and hit the ball."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A stick for hitting a ball? <break time='400ms'/> A cave? <break time='400ms'/> A flying animal? <break time='400ms'/> or A type of bird? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Jake swung it and hit a ball ‚Äî that's baseball!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The exhausted runner sat down after the race."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does exhausted most likely mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Hungry? <break time='400ms'/> Very tired? <break time='400ms'/> Excited? <break time='400ms'/> or Happy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! After a race, how would a runner feel? The sentence gives you context.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> What does ring mean in this sentence?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Did you hear the phone ring?"</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To make a sound? <break time='400ms'/> Jewelry worn on a finger? <break time='400ms'/> A circle shape? <break time='400ms'/> or A boxing area? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You can 'hear' a ring ‚Äî so it must be a sound!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The bright sun made everything glow."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does bright mean here?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Shining with a lot of light? <break time='400ms'/> Dark? <break time='400ms'/> Smart? <break time='400ms'/> or Colorful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sun is shining ‚Äî 'bright' describes how much light it gives off.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The enormous elephant was the biggest animal at the zoo."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word enormous means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Gray? <break time='400ms'/> Slow? <break time='400ms'/> Very large? <break time='400ms'/> or Tiny? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sentence says it was the BIGGEST animal. What word means very big?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The children were famished after playing all day, so they ate a huge dinner."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does famished mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tired? <break time='400ms'/> Silly? <break time='400ms'/> Very hungry? <break time='400ms'/> or Happy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! They ate a huge dinner after playing all day. How did they feel before eating?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Be cautious when crossing the street ‚Äî look both ways first."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does cautious mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Happy? <break time='400ms'/> Loud? <break time='400ms'/> Careful? <break time='400ms'/> or Fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Looking both ways before crossing is something you do to be safe and careful.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The frigid wind made everyone shiver and bundle up in their coats."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word frigid means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Gentle? <break time='400ms'/> Very cold? <break time='400ms'/> Warm? <break time='400ms'/> or Strong? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! People shivered and bundled up. What kind of wind would make you do that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Mom said the movie was hilarious ‚Äî she couldn't stop laughing!"<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does hilarious mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very funny? <break time='400ms'/> Sad? <break time='400ms'/> Scary? <break time='400ms'/> or Boring? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She couldn't stop LAUGHING. What word describes something that makes you laugh?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If happy means feeling good, what does unhappy mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very happy? <break time='400ms'/> Happy again? <break time='400ms'/> Not happy? <break time='400ms'/> or Happy before? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The prefix 'un-' means 'not.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does retell mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tell before? <break time='400ms'/> Tell again? <break time='400ms'/> Not tell? <break time='400ms'/> or Tell for the first time? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The prefix 're-' means 'again.' Re + tell = ?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word preview means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To not view? <break time='400ms'/> To view after? <break time='400ms'/> To view again? <break time='400ms'/> or To view before? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Pre-' means 'before.' Pre + view = view before!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If lock means to close with a key, what does unlock mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Lock it again? <break time='400ms'/> Lock it tighter? <break time='400ms'/> Open with a key? <break time='400ms'/> or A broken lock? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Un-' means 'not' or 'the opposite.' The opposite of locking is...?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does disagree mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To not agree? <break time='400ms'/> To agree before? <break time='400ms'/> To agree strongly? <break time='400ms'/> or To agree again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The prefix 'dis-' means 'not' or 'opposite of.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If teach means to help someone learn, what does a teacher do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Drives a bus? <break time='400ms'/> Helps people learn? <break time='400ms'/> Builds things? <break time='400ms'/> or Cooks food? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The root word is 'teach.' A teacher is a person who teaches!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You know that paint means to put color on something. What does painter mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of paint? <break time='400ms'/> Paint that is old? <break time='400ms'/> A person who paints? <break time='400ms'/> or A painting on a wall? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The '-er' ending often means 'a person who does something.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root word help is in all of these words EXCEPT ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Helper? <break time='400ms'/> Helmet? <break time='400ms'/> Helpless? <break time='400ms'/> or Helpful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look at each word ‚Äî which one does NOT have 'help' in it?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If joy means happiness, what does joyful mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Full of joy? <break time='400ms'/> Before joy? <break time='400ms'/> Without joy? <break time='400ms'/> or Joy again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The root is 'joy' and the suffix '-ful' means 'full of.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You know move means to go from one place to another. What does movement mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Moving fast? <break time='400ms'/> A place to move? <break time='400ms'/> The act of moving? <break time='400ms'/> or Not moving? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The root word 'move' plus '-ment' means 'the act of' something.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does sunflower mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of sunshine? <break time='400ms'/> A flower that blocks the sun? <break time='400ms'/> The sun made of flowers? <break time='400ms'/> or A flower that faces the sun? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Break it apart: sun + flower. It's a flower connected to the sun!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word raincoat is made up of which two words?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rai + ncoat? <break time='400ms'/> Rainco + at? <break time='400ms'/> Rain + coat? <break time='400ms'/> or Ra + incoat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A coat you wear when it rains!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is a bookshelf?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of book? <break time='400ms'/> A shelf for holding books? <break time='400ms'/> A book about shelves? <break time='400ms'/> or A shelf made of books? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Book + shelf. Where do you put books?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If light means something that shines and house means a building, what is a lighthouse?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A building with a bright light to guide ships? <break time='400ms'/> A light inside a house? <break time='400ms'/> A house that is light-colored? <break time='400ms'/> or A house made of light? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about a building (house) with a big shining light. Where would you find this?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is a compound word?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Garden? <break time='400ms'/> Sister? <break time='400ms'/> Butterfly? <break time='400ms'/> or Purple? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A compound word is made of two smaller words put together. Which word can be split?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Where would you find the meaning of a word in a nonfiction book?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The glossary? <break time='400ms'/> The title page? <break time='400ms'/> The back cover? <break time='400ms'/> or The table of contents? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A glossary is a mini-dictionary in the back of a book!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Words in a dictionary are organized ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> By color? <break time='400ms'/> By topic? <break time='400ms'/> By length? <break time='400ms'/> or In alphabetical order? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! To find a word, you need to know the ABC order!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word would come FIRST in a dictionary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cat? <break time='400ms'/> Dog? <break time='400ms'/> Ant? <break time='400ms'/> or Bird? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Which letter comes first in the alphabet: a, b, c, or d?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A glossary is different from a dictionary because ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It's at the front of the book? <break time='400ms'/> It only includes words used in that specific book? <break time='400ms'/> It has more words? <break time='400ms'/> or It has pictures? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A dictionary has ALL words. A glossary has only the words from one book.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You want to look up penguin in the dictionary. Which guide words tell you it's on that page?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Phone ‚Äî picture? <break time='400ms'/> Peach ‚Äî person? <break time='400ms'/> Play ‚Äî plum? <break time='400ms'/> or Paper ‚Äî party? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Guide words show the first and last words on a page. 'Penguin' falls between which pair?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word means almost the same as big?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tiny? <break time='400ms'/> Bright? <break time='400ms'/> Large? <break time='400ms'/> or Fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A synonym is a word with a similar meaning. Which word is similar to 'big'?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is the OPPOSITE of hot?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cold? <break time='400ms'/> Sunny? <break time='400ms'/> Spicy? <break time='400ms'/> or Warm? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The opposite of something very warm would be something very...?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which group of words are all related to weather?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Run, jump, skip? <break time='400ms'/> Book, pen, paper? <break time='400ms'/> Dog, cat, fish? <break time='400ms'/> or Rain, snow, sunny? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Which group has words you'd hear in a weather report?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When would you use the word whisper?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> At a loud concert? <break time='400ms'/> In a library when you need to be quiet? <break time='400ms'/> When calling someone far away? <break time='400ms'/> or While cheering at a game? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Whispering means talking very softly. Where would you need to be quiet?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word means the same as glad?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Scared? <break time='400ms'/> Angry? <break time='400ms'/> Sad? <break time='400ms'/> or Happy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'I'm so glad you're here!' ‚Äî does that sound happy or sad?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which of these foods could be described as crunchy?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Carrots? <break time='400ms'/> Soup? <break time='400ms'/> Ice cream? <break time='400ms'/> or Yogurt? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about which food makes a cracking sound when you bite it.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which action is courageous?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Watching TV? <break time='400ms'/> Sleeping in your bed? <break time='400ms'/> Standing up to a bully? <break time='400ms'/> or Eating lunch? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Courageous' means brave. Which action takes bravery?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When might you feel frustrated?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> When you open a birthday present? <break time='400ms'/> When you eat your favorite food? <break time='400ms'/> When you can't solve a puzzle after many tries? <break time='400ms'/> or When you play with your best friend? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Frustrated means feeling stuck or annoyed because something is hard.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which place would you describe as peaceful?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A crowded mall? <break time='400ms'/> A quiet garden with birds singing? <break time='400ms'/> A construction site? <break time='400ms'/> or A loud gym class? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Peaceful' means calm and quiet. Which place sounds calm?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which animal would you describe as swift?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A snail? <break time='400ms'/> A sloth? <break time='400ms'/> A turtle? <break time='400ms'/> or A cheetah? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Swift' means very fast. Which animal is the fastest?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Put these words in order from LEAST strong to MOST strong: toss, hurl, throw</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Toss ‚Üí throw ‚Üí hurl? <break time='400ms'/> Hurl ‚Üí throw ‚Üí toss? <break time='400ms'/> Toss ‚Üí hurl ‚Üí throw? <break time='400ms'/> or Throw ‚Üí toss ‚Üí hurl? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Tossing is gentle, throwing is normal, hurling is very powerful!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word means being MORE than just warm?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cold? <break time='400ms'/> Hot? <break time='400ms'/> Cool? <break time='400ms'/> or Chilly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If warm goes up in temperature, what's the stronger word?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word shows a BIGGER size than big?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Gigantic? <break time='400ms'/> Medium? <break time='400ms'/> Tiny? <break time='400ms'/> or Small? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Big is large. What word means REALLY, REALLY big?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Put these words in order from quietest to loudest: yell, whisper, talk</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Talk ‚Üí yell ‚Üí whisper? <break time='400ms'/> Yell ‚Üí talk ‚Üí whisper? <break time='400ms'/> Whisper ‚Üí yell ‚Üí talk? <break time='400ms'/> or Whisper ‚Üí talk ‚Üí yell? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Start with the softest voice and end with the loudest.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word means walking SLOWLY and tiredly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> March? <break time='400ms'/> Trudge? <break time='400ms'/> Sprint? <break time='400ms'/> or Skip? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Sprinting is fast, marching is steady, skipping is bouncy. Which one is slow and tired?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses an adjective to describe the dog?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Dogs are pets? <break time='400ms'/> The dog ran? <break time='400ms'/> The fluffy dog ran.? <break time='400ms'/> or The dog ran quickly.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An adjective describes a noun. Which sentence tells you what KIND of dog?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Which word is an adverb in this sentence?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The girl sang beautifully."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Beautifully? <break time='400ms'/> Sang? <break time='400ms'/> Girl? <break time='400ms'/> or The? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An adverb describes HOW something is done. How did she sing?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Fill in the blank with the best adjective:.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The ____ storm knocked down trees."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Happily? <break time='400ms'/> Powerful? <break time='400ms'/> Gently? <break time='400ms'/> or Slowly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You need a word that describes the storm (a noun). Which word tells you what kind of storm?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses an adverb?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He ran quickly to the bus.? <break time='400ms'/> She ate a tasty cookie.? <break time='400ms'/> The cat is orange.? <break time='400ms'/> or The tall tree fell.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An adverb tells HOW, WHEN, or WHERE. Which sentence has a word that tells HOW?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Choose the MOST descriptive sentence:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> I hungrily ate a warm, cheesy sandwich.? <break time='400ms'/> I ate something good.? <break time='400ms'/> I ate a sandwich.? <break time='400ms'/> or I ate food? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The most descriptive sentence uses adjectives and adverbs to paint a picture!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Captain Rosie sailed her tiny boat across the lake every morning. One foggy day, she spotted something glowing beneath the water. She leaned over the side and saw a golden chest resting on the sandy bottom.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What did Captain Rosie find under the water?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A golden chest? <break time='400ms'/> A glowing rock? <break time='400ms'/> A fish? <break time='400ms'/> or A sunken ship? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look at the last sentence ‚Äî what was resting on the sandy bottom?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Marcus had practiced his speech twenty times. When he stepped onto the stage, his hands were shaking. But once he started talking, the words flowed easily, and the audience clapped loudly at the end.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Marcus feel when he first stepped on stage?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Confident and calm? <break time='400ms'/> Angry and upset? <break time='400ms'/> Bored and tired? <break time='400ms'/> or Nervous and shaky? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text says his hands were shaking ‚Äî what feeling does that show?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Grandma Chen kept a garden full of herbs. "Every plant has a story," she told Mei. She pointed to the lavender. "Your grandfather brought those seeds from his village."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Who brought the lavender seeds?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Grandma Chen? <break time='400ms'/> A neighbor? <break time='400ms'/> Mei's grandfather? <break time='400ms'/> or Mei? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Grandma says 'Your grandfather brought those seeds.' Whose grandfather?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The fox crept through the snow, its orange fur bright against the white. It paused, tilted its head, then leaped straight up and dove nose-first into a snowbank. Seconds later, it emerged with a mouse in its jaws.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why did the fox leap into the snowbank?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To play in the snow? <break time='400ms'/> To catch a mouse? <break time='400ms'/> To hide from a predator? <break time='400ms'/> or To cool down? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What did the fox have when it came back out of the snow?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Aisha's violin had belonged to three generations of her family. The wood was worn smooth where countless fingers had pressed the strings. "Play with your heart, not just your hands," her mother always said.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the worn wood tell us about the violin?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It needs to be replaced? <break time='400ms'/> It's been played by many people over many years? <break time='400ms'/> It's brand new? <break time='400ms'/> or It's broken? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text says it belonged to three generations and has smooth, worn wood from countless fingers.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The crow found a piece of cheese. A fox said, "What a beautiful voice you must have! Please sing for me." The crow opened its beak to sing, and the cheese fell right into the fox's mouth.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the moral of this fable?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Don't trust flattery from someone who wants something? <break time='400ms'/> Foxes are faster than crows? <break time='400ms'/> Crows can't sing? <break time='400ms'/> or Cheese is delicious? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The fox used fake compliments to trick the crow. What's the lesson?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A boy cried "Wolf!" when there was no wolf, just to get attention. The villagers came running twice. When a real wolf appeared and the boy cried for help, no one believed him.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the central message?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Wolves are dangerous? <break time='400ms'/> Boys shouldn't be shepherds? <break time='400ms'/> Lying destroys trust? <break time='400ms'/> or Villagers are mean? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! What happened because the boy lied? Nobody believed him when it mattered.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> King Midas wished that everything he touched would turn to gold. His wish came true! But when his food, his flowers, and even his daughter turned to gold, he begged for the wish to be taken away.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What lesson does this myth teach?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Magic always works out well? <break time='400ms'/> Kings are always happy? <break time='400ms'/> Gold is the most valuable thing? <break time='400ms'/> or Be careful what you wish for ‚Äî greed has consequences? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Midas got exactly what he wanted, but it ruined everything he loved.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Two goats met on a narrow bridge over a river. Neither would step aside. They pushed and shoved until both fell into the water below.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the lesson?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Always cross bridges quickly? <break time='400ms'/> Goats can't swim? <break time='400ms'/> Stubbornness and refusing to compromise hurts everyone? <break time='400ms'/> or Bridges are dangerous? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Neither goat would give way. What happened because of that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A young girl named Anansi's daughter was always bragging about being the smartest in her village. One day, the village elder gave her a riddle she couldn't solve. A quiet boy named Kofi, who listened more than he talked, solved it easily.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the central message?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Riddles are hard? <break time='400ms'/> Elders are tricky? <break time='400ms'/> Girls aren't as smart as boys? <break time='400ms'/> or Bragging doesn't make you smart ‚Äî listening and thinking do? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Compare the girl who bragged with the boy who listened. Who succeeded?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Dina noticed her classmate sitting alone at lunch every day. She walked over and said, "Want to sit with us?" Soon they became best friends and started a book club together.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What character trait does Dina show?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Kindness? <break time='400ms'/> Stubbornness? <break time='400ms'/> Laziness? <break time='400ms'/> or Shyness? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Dina noticed someone alone and invited them to join. What kind of person does that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> When the team's star player got hurt, nobody wanted to take her place. Jaylen was nervous, but he stepped up and said, "I'll do it." He scored the winning goal.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Jaylen's action affect the story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The team lost the game? <break time='400ms'/> He got hurt too? <break time='400ms'/> Nothing changed? <break time='400ms'/> or His bravery led to the team winning? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Jaylen volunteered even though he was nervous. What happened because of that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Omar found a wallet on the playground with twenty dollars inside. He thought about keeping it, but instead he brought it to the office. The wallet belonged to a kindergartner's mom.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Omar's action tell us about him?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He doesn't like money? <break time='400ms'/> He is scared of getting caught? <break time='400ms'/> He doesn't need money? <break time='400ms'/> or He is honest and does the right thing? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Omar chose to return the wallet even though he could have kept the money.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Marta refused to share the art supplies with her group. She kept the best markers for herself. The other kids stopped inviting her to work on projects.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What happened BECAUSE of Marta's actions?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She won an art contest? <break time='400ms'/> The teacher praised her? <break time='400ms'/> She got more supplies? <break time='400ms'/> or Her group stopped including her? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Marta's selfishness had a consequence. What was it?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A character who always makes careful plans before acting can be described as ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Fearful? <break time='400ms'/> Reckless? <break time='400ms'/> Impatient? <break time='400ms'/> or Thoughtful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Someone who thinks carefully before doing something is being thought-ful!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> After winning the race, Kenji was on top of the world.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does on top of the world mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He was very tall? <break time='400ms'/> He was standing on a globe? <break time='400ms'/> He was extremely happy? <break time='400ms'/> or He climbed a mountain? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is figurative language ‚Äî it doesn't literally mean he's on top of the world!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Don't let the cat out of the bag," whispered Mom before the surprise party.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does "let the cat out of the bag" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Release an actual cat? <break time='400ms'/> Feed a pet? <break time='400ms'/> Reveal a secret? <break time='400ms'/> or Open a bag? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Mom is talking about keeping the surprise party a secret!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses LITERAL language?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Time flies when you're having fun.? <break time='400ms'/> She has a heart of gold.? <break time='400ms'/> He was drowning in homework.? <break time='400ms'/> or The dog ate his dinner.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Literal language means exactly what it says ‚Äî no hidden meaning.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The classroom was a zoo today!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They went on a field trip to the zoo? <break time='400ms'/> The teacher likes animals? <break time='400ms'/> There were animals in the classroom? <break time='400ms'/> or The classroom was very loud and chaotic? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The classroom isn't ACTUALLY a zoo ‚Äî the author is comparing it to one. Why?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The icy wind bit at their faces as they walked to school.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does bit at their faces mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Their faces were frozen solid? <break time='400ms'/> They were eating something cold? <break time='400ms'/> The wind felt sharp and painful on their skin? <break time='400ms'/> or An animal bit them? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Wind can't actually bite! The author is describing how the cold FELT.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A group of lines in a poem is called a ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Scene? <break time='400ms'/> Paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> Stanza? <break time='400ms'/> or Chapter? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Chapters are for books, paragraphs for essays, scenes for plays. What about poems?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a play, when the setting or time changes, a new ____ begins.</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Scene? <break time='400ms'/> Chapter? <break time='400ms'/> Paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> or Stanza? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Plays are divided into acts and these smaller parts.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A long novel is usually divided into ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Chapters? <break time='400ms'/> Verses? <break time='400ms'/> Scenes? <break time='400ms'/> or Stanzas? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about how a novel is organized ‚Äî each section has a number and sometimes a title.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If a poem has four stanzas, each with four lines, how many lines does the poem have in total?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 12? <break time='400ms'/> 8? <break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> or 16? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Four stanzas times four lines each equals...?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which text type uses the word scene to describe its parts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A newspaper article? <break time='400ms'/> A novel? <break time='400ms'/> A play or drama? <break time='400ms'/> or A poem? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! When actors perform on stage, each part of the show is a...?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The narrator says, "Vegetables are the most boring food in the world."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is the point of view of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The author's final opinion? <break time='400ms'/> The narrator or character? <break time='400ms'/> All people everywhere? <break time='400ms'/> or A scientist? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Just because a character says something doesn't mean everyone agrees!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A character in a story thinks it's okay to cheat on a test. You think cheating is wrong. This shows that ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> You and the character have different points of view? <break time='400ms'/> You didn't understand the story? <break time='400ms'/> The character is always right? <break time='400ms'/> or The story is wrong? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It's normal to disagree with a character! That's having a different point of view.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> I hated moving to a new town. Everything was different and terrible. But by the end of the year, I had the best friends I'd ever had.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Who is telling this story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> An outside narrator? <break time='400ms'/> The main character, using 'I'? <break time='400ms'/> A teacher? <break time='400ms'/> or A parent watching their child? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'I' tells you this is first-person ‚Äî the character is telling their own story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is it important to notice the narrator's point of view?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It's not important at all? <break time='400ms'/> Because there's only one way to see a story? <break time='400ms'/> Because narrators are always right? <break time='400ms'/> or Because it helps you understand who is telling the story and how they see things? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Different narrators might tell the same story in very different ways!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The wolf in the story said he was just trying to borrow sugar. But the pigs said he tried to blow their houses down.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>A reader might think ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The wolf is definitely telling the truth? <break time='400ms'/> The pigs are definitely lying? <break time='400ms'/> Both characters have their own version of events, and the reader can decide? <break time='400ms'/> or Neither character matters? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! As a reader, YOU get to think about both sides and form your own opinion!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A story says "The girl walked into the room." The illustration shows the room decorated with balloons, streamers, and a big cake. The illustration helps show that ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The girl is at school? <break time='400ms'/> The room is empty? <break time='400ms'/> There's a party or celebration happening? <break time='400ms'/> or The girl is sad? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words just say she walked in, but the PICTURE adds all those party details!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>An illustration uses dark colors and shadows. This most likely creates a mood that is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Mysterious or scary? <break time='400ms'/> Happy and cheerful? <break time='400ms'/> Silly and funny? <break time='400ms'/> or Bright and exciting? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Dark colors and shadows make things feel spooky or tense.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a picture book, the text says the character is "fine." But the illustration shows tears in the character's eyes. What does the illustration tell us?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The illustrator made a mistake? <break time='400ms'/> The character is lying about their feelings? <break time='400ms'/> The character really is fine? <break time='400ms'/> or The character is laughing? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words say 'fine' but the picture shows tears ‚Äî those don't match!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How can an illustration emphasize a character's personality?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Illustrations can't show personality? <break time='400ms'/> By writing the character's name in big letters? <break time='400ms'/> By showing the character's clothing, expression, and posture? <break time='400ms'/> or By using only black and white? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about how someone LOOKS ‚Äî messy or neat, smiling or frowning, tall and proud or hunched over.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A story describes a "small cottage." The illustration shows it surrounded by enormous trees and a vast mountain range. How does the illustration add to the story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It changes the story? <break time='400ms'/> It shows the cottage is actually big? <break time='400ms'/> It doesn't add anything? <break time='400ms'/> or It emphasizes how small the cottage is compared to nature? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The huge trees and mountains around the tiny cottage show just how small it is!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>An author writes two books about a character named Max. In Book 1, Max learns to be brave at summer camp. In Book 2, Max learns to be brave at a new school. What is SIMILAR in both books?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The setting? <break time='400ms'/> The theme of learning bravery? <break time='400ms'/> The ending? <break time='400ms'/> or The other characters? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both books are about the same big idea ‚Äî bravery. That's the theme!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Two stories by the same author are set in different places ‚Äî one in a city and one on a farm. But both stories are about friendship. What is DIFFERENT between the stories?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The theme? <break time='400ms'/> The message? <break time='400ms'/> The setting? <break time='400ms'/> or The moral? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A city and a farm are two different places. That's the setting!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In Story 1, a girl solves a mystery at her school. In Story 2 by the same author, the same girl solves a mystery at a museum. What changed between the stories?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The author? <break time='400ms'/> The main character? <break time='400ms'/> The type of story? <break time='400ms'/> or The setting and specific plot? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Same girl, same type of story (mystery), but different place and different mystery!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why might an author write multiple books about the same character?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Readers enjoy following a character through new adventures? <break time='400ms'/> They have to write sequels? <break time='400ms'/> It's easier to copy the same story? <break time='400ms'/> or They can't think of new characters? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about book series you love ‚Äî why do you want to read the next one?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When comparing two stories, which of these would be a CONTRAST (difference)?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both teach a lesson about kindness? <break time='400ms'/> One takes place in winter and the other in summer? <break time='400ms'/> Both are written by the same author? <break time='400ms'/> or Both have the same main character? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A contrast is something that's DIFFERENT between the two stories.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The old woman lived at the edge of the forest where the trees whispered secrets to one another. Every evening, she placed a lantern in her window. "For the lost travelers," she told the cat, who blinked slowly as if he understood.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why does the old woman place a lantern in her window?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She's afraid of the dark? <break time='400ms'/> To scare away animals? <break time='400ms'/> To guide lost travelers? <break time='400ms'/> or Because she likes fire? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She says it herself ‚Äî 'For the lost travelers.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:
