script_text: <speak> Diego had exactly one week to build his invention for the science fair. On Monday he sketched plans. By Wednesday, he'd used all his supplies and started over. On Friday, with tape on his fingers and glue in his hair, he stepped back and grinned.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer about Diego?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He gave up easily? <break time='400ms'/> He had help from a friend? <break time='400ms'/> He was persistent and creative despite setbacks? <break time='400ms'/> or He didn't care about the science fair? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! He started over but kept going. By Friday, he was grinning. What does that tell you?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "You can't climb that," said every kid on the block. Sana looked up at the ancient oak, its branches reaching like outstretched arms. She grabbed the lowest branch and pulled herself up.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The phrase "branches reaching like outstretched arms" is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Literal description? <break time='400ms'/> A simile comparing branches to arms? <break time='400ms'/> A fact about trees? <break time='400ms'/> or A character's thoughts? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'like' compares two things ‚Äî branches and outstretched arms.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The package sat on the porch for three days. Each morning, Eliot walked past it. Each evening, he wondered what was inside. On the fourth day, he finally picked it up and read the label: "To Eliot, from your future self."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the author trying to make the reader feel?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Curious and intrigued? <break time='400ms'/> Bored? <break time='400ms'/> Angry? <break time='400ms'/> or Sleepy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A package from your FUTURE self? The author builds mystery to make you want to know more!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Everyone said the old house was haunted. Lina didn't believe in ghosts. She marched up the creaky steps, pushed open the door, and found... a family of raccoons living in the fireplace.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What makes this ending effective?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It leaves everything unresolved? <break time='400ms'/> It confirms the house is haunted? <break time='400ms'/> It's scary? <break time='400ms'/> or It surprises the reader with a funny, unexpected twist? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You expected something spooky, but got raccoons! That surprise is what makes it work.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Amazon Rainforest produces about 20 percent of the world's oxygen. It is home to more than 10 million species of plants and animals.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How much of the world's oxygen does the Amazon produce?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> About 80 percent? <break time='400ms'/> About 10 percent? <break time='400ms'/> About 20 percent? <break time='400ms'/> or About 50 percent? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The percentage is stated in the first sentence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Harriet Tubman escaped slavery in 1849. She then risked her life many times to help others escape through the Underground Railroad. She led about 70 people to freedom.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many people did Harriet Tubman help escape?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> About 700? <break time='400ms'/> About 17? <break time='400ms'/> About 70? <break time='400ms'/> or About 170? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The last sentence gives you the exact number.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Earthquakes happen when large pieces of the Earth's crust, called tectonic plates, suddenly move. Most earthquakes occur along the edges of these plates.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What causes earthquakes?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Heavy rain? <break time='400ms'/> Tectonic plates suddenly moving? <break time='400ms'/> Volcanoes erupting? <break time='400ms'/> or Strong winds? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence explains exactly what causes them.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Thomas Edison failed over 1,000 times before successfully inventing the light bulb. He once said, "I have not failed. I've just found 1,000 ways that won't work."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Edison's quote tell us about his attitude?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He didn't care about inventing? <break time='400ms'/> He thought 1,000 failures was too many? <break time='400ms'/> He was ready to give up? <break time='400ms'/> or He saw failures as learning experiences? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! He didn't call them failures ‚Äî he called them ways that won't work. That's a positive attitude!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The International Space Station orbits Earth about every 90 minutes, traveling at 17,500 miles per hour. Astronauts aboard the station see 16 sunrises and sunsets every day.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why do astronauts see 16 sunrises each day?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> There are 16 suns? <break time='400ms'/> Days are longer in space? <break time='400ms'/> The sun moves faster in space? <break time='400ms'/> or The station orbits Earth so quickly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It goes around Earth every 90 minutes ‚Äî so it sees the sun rise and set with each orbit!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Bees are essential to our food supply. They pollinate flowers that grow into fruits and vegetables. Without bees, we would lose about one-third of the food we eat.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main idea?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bees are important for our food supply? <break time='400ms'/> Fruits and vegetables are healthy? <break time='400ms'/> Flowers need sunlight? <break time='400ms'/> or Bees make honey? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence states the main idea. The rest gives supporting details.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Sleep is important for kids. During sleep, your brain stores what you learned that day. Your body grows and repairs itself. Kids who get enough sleep do better in school.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which detail supports the idea that sleep helps learning?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Sleep is important for kids? <break time='400ms'/> Your brain stores what you learned? <break time='400ms'/> Kids do better in school? <break time='400ms'/> or Your body grows? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Which detail specifically connects sleep to LEARNING?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Coral reefs are in danger. Pollution poisons the water. Rising temperatures cause coral to turn white and die. Overfishing removes animals that keep reefs healthy.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The key details all support the main idea that ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Coral reefs are beautiful? <break time='400ms'/> Fish live in reefs? <break time='400ms'/> The ocean is cold? <break time='400ms'/> or Coral reefs face many threats? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Pollution, rising temperatures, overfishing ‚Äî these are all threats!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How do you find the main idea of a passage?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Count the sentences? <break time='400ms'/> Read only the first word? <break time='400ms'/> Look at the last sentence only? <break time='400ms'/> or Think about what all the details have in common? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The main idea is the big umbrella that all the details fit under.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ancient Egyptians invented many things we still use today. They created one of the first writing systems called hieroglyphics. They developed a 365-day calendar. They even invented toothpaste!<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main idea?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ancient Egypt had a calendar? <break time='400ms'/> Ancient Egyptians were great inventors? <break time='400ms'/> Egyptians liked to write? <break time='400ms'/> or Toothpaste is important? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The passage lists several inventions. What big idea ties them together?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Because the river flooded, farmers lost their crops. As a result, food prices went up that year.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What caused food prices to go up?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Farmers lost crops due to flooding? <break time='400ms'/> Too many people buying food? <break time='400ms'/> A new law about food? <break time='400ms'/> or High temperatures? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Follow the chain: flood ‚Üí lost crops ‚Üí higher food prices.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> First, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat in 1955. Then, the Montgomery Bus Boycott began. Finally, the Supreme Court ruled bus segregation was unconstitutional.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which event happened FIRST?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The boycott? <break time='400ms'/> The Supreme Court ruling? <break time='400ms'/> Bus segregation began? <break time='400ms'/> or Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'First' tells you the sequence!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The words because, "as a result," and therefore signal what type of relationship?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Chronological order? <break time='400ms'/> Problem and solution? <break time='400ms'/> Cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> or Compare and contrast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! These words show that one thing CAUSED another thing to happen.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Scientists noticed that temperatures were rising globally. This led to melting ice caps, which caused sea levels to rise.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the EFFECT of melting ice caps?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ice caps grow larger? <break time='400ms'/> Temperatures rise? <break time='400ms'/> Sea levels rise? <break time='400ms'/> or More snow falls? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Melting ice caps CAUSED what to happen next?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> After the Great Fire of London in 1666, the city was rebuilt with stone and brick instead of wood. This made buildings much safer from future fires.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How are these two events connected?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The stone buildings caused the fire? <break time='400ms'/> The fire caused the city to change how it built buildings? <break time='400ms'/> London stopped building after the fire? <break time='400ms'/> or They are not connected? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The fire was the cause. Rebuilding with stone was the effect.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make their own food.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is photosynthesis?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How plants grow roots? <break time='400ms'/> A type of plant? <break time='400ms'/> A chemical in soil? <break time='400ms'/> or How plants make food using sunlight? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The sentence defines it right after the word!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Constitution is the supreme law of the United States. It establishes the structure of the government and protects citizens" rights.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does supreme mean in this context?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Old? <break time='400ms'/> Secret? <break time='400ms'/> Written on paper? <break time='400ms'/> or Highest or most important? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The Constitution is the law that all other laws must follow ‚Äî it's the top one!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Erosion is the gradual wearing away of land by water, wind, or ice. Over thousands of years, erosion carved the Grand Canyon.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does gradual mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Sudden and fast? <break time='400ms'/> Underground? <break time='400ms'/> Happening slowly over time? <break time='400ms'/> or Very large? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It took THOUSANDS of years. That's definitely not fast!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Herbivores are animals that eat only plants. Deer, rabbits, and cows are all herbivores.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>A herbivore eats ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Only insects? <break time='400ms'/> Only plants? <break time='400ms'/> Both meat and plants? <break time='400ms'/> or Only meat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence tells you the definition right away.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The expedition to the South Pole took months of preparation. The team packed food, fuel, and navigation equipment for the dangerous journey.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is an expedition?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of equipment? <break time='400ms'/> A long journey for a specific purpose? <break time='400ms'/> A type of fuel? <break time='400ms'/> or A map? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It took months of preparation for a dangerous journey to the South Pole.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You want to find information about volcanoes on page 47 of a textbook. Which text feature would help you find page 47 the fastest?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The title page? <break time='400ms'/> The index? <break time='400ms'/> The glossary? <break time='400ms'/> or A caption? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The index lists topics alphabetically with page numbers!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A sidebar in a textbook usually contains ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The table of contents? <break time='400ms'/> The glossary? <break time='400ms'/> The main text of the chapter? <break time='400ms'/> or Extra interesting facts or related information? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Sidebars are those boxes on the side of a page with bonus information!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You're researching dolphins online. Which search term would give you the BEST results?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Blue things in the ocean? <break time='400ms'/> Cute stuff? <break time='400ms'/> Dolphin habitat and diet? <break time='400ms'/> or Animals? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Specific keywords help you find exactly what you need!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the difference between an index and a glossary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> An index lists topics with page numbers; a glossary defines words? <break time='400ms'/> An index is at the front; a glossary is in the middle? <break time='400ms'/> They are the same thing? <break time='400ms'/> or An index defines words; a glossary lists page numbers? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Index = find WHERE something is. Glossary = find WHAT a word means.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Hyperlinks in a digital text allow you to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Delete words? <break time='400ms'/> Jump to related information quickly? <break time='400ms'/> Change the font size? <break time='400ms'/> or Print the page? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clicking a hyperlink takes you to another page or section with more information!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Homework is valuable because it helps students practice what they learned in class.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author's point of view is that homework is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Only for math? <break time='400ms'/> Valuable for learning? <break time='400ms'/> Too easy? <break time='400ms'/> or A waste of time? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author uses the word 'valuable' ‚Äî that tells you they think homework is good.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A student reads an article that says school should start later. The student likes waking up early. This shows ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The student and author have different points of view? <break time='400ms'/> The student is wrong? <break time='400ms'/> The article is bad? <break time='400ms'/> or The author is wrong? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It's okay to disagree with an author! That's having your own point of view.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How can you figure out an author's point of view?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Look at the words they choose and what they emphasize? <break time='400ms'/> Count the paragraphs? <break time='400ms'/> Ask the author directly? <break time='400ms'/> or Read only the title? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Authors reveal their opinions through their word choices and what they focus on.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Zoos keep animals in small spaces where they can't roam freely. Animals deserve to live in their natural habitats.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author most likely believes ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> All animals should be pets? <break time='400ms'/> Zoos aren't the best place for animals? <break time='400ms'/> Animals are happier in zoos? <break time='400ms'/> or Zoos are great for animals? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Words like 'small spaces' and 'deserve to live in natural habitats' show the author's opinion.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is it important to recognize your OWN point of view when reading?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> So you can think critically and form your own opinions? <break time='400ms'/> It's not important? <break time='400ms'/> So you can argue with everyone? <break time='400ms'/> or So you always agree with the author? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers don't just accept everything ‚Äî they think about it and decide for themselves!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A science text describes the water cycle. Beside it is a diagram with arrows showing evaporation, condensation, and precipitation. The diagram helps by ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Showing the process visually so it's easier to understand? <break time='400ms'/> Adding new vocabulary? <break time='400ms'/> Replacing the text? <break time='400ms'/> or Making the page look nice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Diagrams show you HOW something works in a way words alone can't.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A map in a history book shows the route Lewis and Clark traveled. The map helps readers understand ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How far and where they traveled? <break time='400ms'/> What they ate? <break time='400ms'/> When they were born? <break time='400ms'/> or What the explorers looked like? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Maps show locations and distances!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A photograph in a textbook shows a volcano erupting with lava flowing down its side. The photograph adds to the text by ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Listing vocabulary words? <break time='400ms'/> Explaining the science of volcanoes? <break time='400ms'/> Showing what an eruption actually looks like? <break time='400ms'/> or Providing a map? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Photos show real-world images that help you picture what the text describes.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A bar graph in a text about favorite school lunches shows pizza at 45%, tacos at 30%, and salad at 25%. What information does the graph give that the text might not?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The recipes? <break time='400ms'/> The exact percentages at a glance? <break time='400ms'/> Who cooked the food? <break time='400ms'/> or What time lunch is served? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Graphs let you quickly SEE and COMPARE numbers!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which illustration would BEST help a reader understand an article about the layers of the Earth?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A map of the continents? <break time='400ms'/> A picture of a mountain? <break time='400ms'/> A cross-section diagram showing the crust, mantle, and core? <break time='400ms'/> or A photo of a sunset? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You can't SEE inside the Earth, so a diagram that shows a cross-section is the best way!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Sentence 1: Plastic bags harm ocean animals. Sentence 2: Sea turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and eat them.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Sentence 2 connects to Sentence 1 by ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Giving an example of how plastic harms animals? <break time='400ms'/> Introducing a new idea? <break time='400ms'/> Changing the topic? <break time='400ms'/> or Disagreeing with Sentence 1? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Sentence 1 makes a general point. Sentence 2 gives a specific example!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Paragraph 1 describes what earthquakes are. Paragraph 2 explains what causes them.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How are these paragraphs connected?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They contrast each other? <break time='400ms'/> They tell a story in order? <break time='400ms'/> They are about different topics? <break time='400ms'/> or The first defines the topic and the second explains the cause? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! First you learn WHAT something is, then WHY it happens. That's a logical order!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Dogs are loyal pets. However, they require a lot of time and attention.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word however shows ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> A time sequence? <break time='400ms'/> A contrast or opposing point? <break time='400ms'/> or Agreement between the two ideas? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'However' signals that the next idea is different from or opposite to the first.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A paragraph about saving water is followed by a paragraph listing specific ways to save water at home. The second paragraph ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Disagrees with the first? <break time='400ms'/> Tells a personal story? <break time='400ms'/> Provides specific examples to support the first paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> or Changes the topic completely? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! General idea ‚Üí specific examples. That's a common way paragraphs connect!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which signal words show a sequence (order) connection between sentences?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Because, therefore, as a result? <break time='400ms'/> First, next, then, finally? <break time='400ms'/> However, but, although? <break time='400ms'/> or For example, such as? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! These words tell you the ORDER things happen in!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A about sharks focuses on how they hunt. Text B about sharks focuses on why they're endangered. What do both texts have in common?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both focus on hunting? <break time='400ms'/> Both are about sharks? <break time='400ms'/> Both are about fishing? <break time='400ms'/> or Both focus on endangerment? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The topic is the same ‚Äî sharks. But each text focuses on a different aspect.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Text A says: "Exercise is important because it keeps your heart healthy." Text B says: "Exercise is important because it improves mood and reduces stress."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is DIFFERENT between the two texts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They disagree about exercise? <break time='400ms'/> They focus on different BENEFITS of exercise? <break time='400ms'/> One is wrong? <break time='400ms'/> or One is about food? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both agree exercise is important ‚Äî but they highlight different reasons!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When comparing two texts, which question is MOST useful?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Which text was written first?? <break time='400ms'/> What information is in both, and what is only in one?? <break time='400ms'/> Which text has bigger pictures?? <break time='400ms'/> or Which text is longer?? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The best comparison looks at what's shared AND what's unique to each text.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Text A: "Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system." Text B: "Mars once had flowing water on its surface."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>These texts provide ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The same exact information? <break time='400ms'/> Information about different planets? <break time='400ms'/> Different facts about the same planet? <break time='400ms'/> or Contradicting facts? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both are about Mars, but each shares a different interesting detail.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A argues that screen time should be limited. Text B argues that educational screen time can be beneficial. A reader should ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ignore both texts? <break time='400ms'/> Consider both viewpoints and think critically? <break time='400ms'/> Only believe Text A? <break time='400ms'/> or Only believe Text B? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers think about different perspectives before forming their own opinion!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Great Barrier Reef stretches over 1,400 miles along Australia's coast. It's so large it can be seen from space. Made up of billions of tiny organisms called coral polyps, it is the largest living structure on Earth.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What are coral polyps?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Fish? <break time='400ms'/> Rocks? <break time='400ms'/> Tiny organisms that make up the reef? <break time='400ms'/> or Types of seaweed? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text describes them as 'tiny organisms called coral polyps.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Unlike most spiders, tarantulas don't spin webs to catch prey. Instead, they hunt by ambushing insects and small animals. Despite their scary appearance, most tarantulas are harmless to humans.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is surprising about tarantulas based on this text?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They are harmless despite looking scary? <break time='400ms'/> They spin webs? <break time='400ms'/> They are very small? <break time='400ms'/> or They only eat plants? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'despite' signals something unexpected ‚Äî scary-looking but harmless!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed that mold had accidentally grown on one of his petri dishes. The bacteria around the mold had died. This accidental discovery led to the development of penicillin, the world's first antibiotic.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What made Fleming's discovery unusual?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It happened by accident? <break time='400ms'/> He was looking for mold? <break time='400ms'/> He worked alone? <break time='400ms'/> or He planned it carefully? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text uses the word 'accidentally' ‚Äî Fleming didn't plan this discovery!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from Canada to Mexico each fall. No single butterfly makes the entire round trip ‚Äî it takes multiple generations. The butterflies that fly south in fall are the great-great-grandchildren of the ones that flew north in spring.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is the monarch migration remarkable?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They fly very slowly? <break time='400ms'/> They only travel short distances? <break time='400ms'/> Multiple generations complete what no single butterfly could? <break time='400ms'/> or They migrate in summer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The great-great-grandchildren finish the journey their ancestors started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Sahara Desert isn't just sand ‚Äî only about 25% is sandy. The rest includes rocky plateaus, gravel plains, and even mountains. Temperatures can swing from over 130¬∞F during the day to below freezing at night.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What common misconception about the Sahara does this text correct?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> That it's all sand? <break time='400ms'/> That it's hot? <break time='400ms'/> That it's in Africa? <break time='400ms'/> or That it's the largest desert? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text starts by saying the Sahara ISN'T just sand, then explains what else is there.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the root word in uncomfortable?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Able? <break time='400ms'/> Table? <break time='400ms'/> Comfort? <break time='400ms'/> or Un? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Remove the prefix 'un-' and suffix '-able.' What's left?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in the word important?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 2? <break time='400ms'/> 3? <break time='400ms'/> or 5? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it out: im-por-tant. Count the claps!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has the same tion sound as nation?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cotton? <break time='400ms'/> Button? <break time='400ms'/> Station? <break time='400ms'/> or Mitten? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say each word. Which one ends with that 'shun' sound like 'nation'?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In the word knight, which letters are silent?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> G and t? <break time='400ms'/> N and h? <break time='400ms'/> K and h? <break time='400ms'/> or K and g? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'knight' out loud. You hear 'nite' ‚Äî which letters are you NOT hearing?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Break the word basketball into syllables:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bask-et-ball? <break time='400ms'/> Bas-ket-ball? <break time='400ms'/> Basket-ball? <break time='400ms'/> or Ba-sket-ball? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This compound-style word has three natural breaks.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The prefix dis- in disagree means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Before? <break time='400ms'/> Not or opposite? <break time='400ms'/> Again? <break time='400ms'/> or Very? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If you disagree, you do NOT agree.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the suffix -ment mean in the word enjoyment?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Full of? <break time='400ms'/> Again? <break time='400ms'/> The act or state of? <break time='400ms'/> or Without? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Enjoyment = the act or state of enjoying!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If pre- means before, what does preview mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To not view? <break time='400ms'/> To view after? <break time='400ms'/> To view before? <break time='400ms'/> or To view again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Pre = before. View = see. So preview = see before!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word uses the suffix -able correctly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Readable? <break time='400ms'/> Jumpable? <break time='400ms'/> Swimable? <break time='400ms'/> or Runable? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! '-able' means 'can be done.' Which one sounds right and is a real word?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The prefix mis- in misunderstand means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very? <break time='400ms'/> Not? <break time='400ms'/> Before? <break time='400ms'/> or Wrongly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If you misunderstand something, you understand it WRONGLY.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What sound does -tion make at the end of a word?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ton? <break time='400ms'/> Tee-on? <break time='400ms'/> Shun? <break time='400ms'/> or Tye-on? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'nation' ‚Äî the '-tion' sounds like 'shun.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word ends with the -sion suffix?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Lesson? <break time='400ms'/> Person? <break time='400ms'/> Mission? <break time='400ms'/> or Kitten? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! '-sion' also makes the 'shun' sound. Which word has it?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The suffix -ible in visible means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Able to be? <break time='400ms'/> Without? <break time='400ms'/> Before? <break time='400ms'/> or Full of? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Visible = able to be seen. So '-ible' means able to be!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word has a Latin suffix?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Education? <break time='400ms'/> Softly? <break time='400ms'/> Biggest? <break time='400ms'/> or Running? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! '-tion' is a Latin suffix commonly found in English words.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word invention breaks into which parts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Inven + tion? <break time='400ms'/> In + vent + ion? <break time='400ms'/> In + vention? <break time='400ms'/> or Invent + ion? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The root word is 'invent' and the suffix is '-ion.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in unbelievable?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 6? <break time='400ms'/> 5? <break time='400ms'/> or 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it: un-be-liev-a-ble. That's five claps!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Break adventure into syllables:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Adven-ture? <break time='400ms'/> A-dvent-ure? <break time='400ms'/> Ad-ven-ture? <break time='400ms'/> or Ad-ventu-re? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Three syllables: ad, ven, ture.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which strategy helps you read a long, unfamiliar word?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Guess based on the first letter? <break time='400ms'/> Read it backwards? <break time='400ms'/> Break it into smaller parts and sound out each part? <break time='400ms'/> or Skip it entirely? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Chunk the word into syllables, then put the sounds together!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in helicopter?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 2? <break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 3? <break time='400ms'/> or 5? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it: hel-i-cop-ter.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Break independent into syllables:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In-de-pen-dent? <break time='400ms'/> In-dep-end-ent? <break time='400ms'/> Indepen-dent? <break time='400ms'/> or Inde-pend-ent? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Four syllables: in, de, pen, dent.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is spelled correctly?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Enuff? <break time='400ms'/> Enough? <break time='400ms'/> Enugh? <break time='400ms'/> or Enuf? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This tricky word has 'ough' ‚Äî which doesn't sound like it looks!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Choose the correct spelling:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Thought? <break time='400ms'/> Thoght? <break time='400ms'/> Thougth? <break time='400ms'/> or Thawt? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Another 'ough' word! Thought has a silent 'gh.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word through rhymes with ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cough? <break time='400ms'/> Rough? <break time='400ms'/> Blue? <break time='400ms'/> or Though? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Say 'through' ‚Äî it sounds like 'threw.' What rhymes with that?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which of these words has a silent w?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Window? <break time='400ms'/> Write? <break time='400ms'/> Water? <break time='400ms'/> or Winter? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! One of these words has a 'w' you don't actually pronounce!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Choose the correct spelling of the word that means having knowledge:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Nolege? <break time='400ms'/> Knowlege? <break time='400ms'/> Knowledge? <break time='400ms'/> or Knoledge? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This word starts with a silent 'k' and has 'ledge' at the end.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does it mean to read with expression?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reading every word the same way? <break time='400ms'/> Changing your voice to show feelings and meaning? <break time='400ms'/> Reading silently? <break time='400ms'/> or Reading very fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Expression means your voice shows the emotions in the text!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A fluent reader ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reads smoothly and at a natural pace? <break time='400ms'/> Reads very slowly, word by word? <break time='400ms'/> Skips hard words? <break time='400ms'/> or Never makes mistakes? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Fluent reading sounds natural, like a conversation.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You're reading aloud and you mispronounce a word. What should you do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Stop reading completely? <break time='400ms'/> Keep going and hope nobody noticed? <break time='400ms'/> Go back, correct the word, and reread the sentence? <break time='400ms'/> or Ask someone to finish for you? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers self-correct! Go back and fix it.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How should you read this sentence? "'Watch out!" screamed the lifeguard."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very slowly? <break time='400ms'/> In a bored tone? <break time='400ms'/> In a quiet, calm voice? <break time='400ms'/> or In a loud, urgent voice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The lifeguard SCREAMED ‚Äî so read it with urgency!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Reading accuracy means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Finishing the book quickly? <break time='400ms'/> Reading with a loud voice? <break time='400ms'/> Reading each word correctly? <break time='400ms'/> or Reading fast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Accuracy = getting the words right!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The octopus is a master of disguise. It can change its color, texture, and even shape to match its surroundings in less than a second.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What makes the octopus a master of disguise?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It can change color, texture, and shape instantly? <break time='400ms'/> It's very fast? <break time='400ms'/> It lives in deep water? <break time='400ms'/> or It hides in shells? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The second sentence lists all the amazing things it can change!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Setting a purpose for reading means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reading out loud? <break time='400ms'/> Picking the longest book? <break time='400ms'/> Reading as fast as possible? <break time='400ms'/> or Knowing what you want to learn or find out before you start? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Having a goal helps you focus and understand better!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Benjamin Franklin was not only a Founding Father but also an inventor. He invented bifocal glasses, the lightning rod, and a more efficient fireplace called the Franklin stove.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What were three of Franklin's inventions?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bifocals, lightning rod, and Franklin stove? <break time='400ms'/> Books, newspapers, and maps? <break time='400ms'/> The telephone, light bulb, and car? <break time='400ms'/> or The Constitution, the flag, and the dollar? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The second sentence lists his three inventions.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Unlike most fish, seahorses swim upright and are surprisingly slow swimmers. The dwarf seahorse holds the record as the slowest fish in the ocean, moving at just 5 feet per hour.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is unusual about how seahorses swim?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They can fly? <break time='400ms'/> They swim backwards? <break time='400ms'/> They swim upright instead of horizontally? <break time='400ms'/> or They swim in circles? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text says 'unlike most fish' ‚Äî what do seahorses do differently?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>After reading a passage, what should you be able to do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Spell every word correctly? <break time='400ms'/> Draw a perfect picture of it? <break time='400ms'/> Recite every word from memory? <break time='400ms'/> or Explain the main idea and key details in your own words? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Understanding means you can talk about what you read in your own words!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When reading a poem aloud, you should ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Pay attention to rhythm and pause at line breaks? <break time='400ms'/> Skip the rhyming words? <break time='400ms'/> Read as fast as possible? <break time='400ms'/> or Read in a monotone voice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Poems have a special rhythm ‚Äî reading them well means following that beat!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How should you read this line? "'Please," she begged quietly, "don't go.'"</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In a soft, pleading voice? <break time='400ms'/> In an angry voice? <break time='400ms'/> As fast as possible? <break time='400ms'/> or In a loud, happy voice? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She 'begged quietly' ‚Äî match your voice to that!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does appropriate rate mean when reading aloud?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> So slow every word takes 5 seconds? <break time='400ms'/> At a constant speed with no changes? <break time='400ms'/> At a speed that sounds natural and allows understanding? <break time='400ms'/> or As fast as you can? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Not too fast, not too slow ‚Äî like how you'd tell a friend a story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A passage has a tense, exciting action scene. How should your reading change?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Slow down and get quieter? <break time='400ms'/> Read in a bored voice? <break time='400ms'/> Speed up slightly and add energy to your voice? <break time='400ms'/> or Stop reading entirely? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Match the energy of the scene ‚Äî exciting moments need exciting reading!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When reading dialogue between two characters, what should you do?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Skip the dialogue? <break time='400ms'/> Use a slightly different voice for each character? <break time='400ms'/> Only read one character's lines? <break time='400ms'/> or Read both characters the same way? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Different voices help listeners know which character is speaking!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You read the word desert as dessert in this sentence: "The camel walked across the hot desert." How do you know you made a mistake?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Camels eat dessert? <break time='400ms'/> Dessert doesn't make sense in a sentence about camels and heat? <break time='400ms'/> The sentence has too many words? <break time='400ms'/> or You can never make mistakes? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Camels don't walk across dessert! The context tells you the word should be 'desert.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is self-correcting when reading?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> You notice your own mistake and fix it? <break time='400ms'/> Someone else fixes your mistakes? <break time='400ms'/> You erase and rewrite? <break time='400ms'/> or You stop reading? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Self' means you do it yourself. 'Correcting' means fixing!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The scientist used a microscope to examine the tiny ____." Which word fits best?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Mountain? <break time='400ms'/> Building? <break time='400ms'/> Organisms? <break time='400ms'/> or Elephant? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A microscope looks at TINY things. Which answer is something tiny a scientist would study?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If you read a paragraph and it doesn't make sense, the BEST thing to do is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Reread the paragraph more carefully? <break time='400ms'/> Close the book? <break time='400ms'/> Move on to the next chapter? <break time='400ms'/> or Read it faster? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Slowing down and rereading helps you catch what you missed!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You read wind as rhyming with find in this sentence: "The wind blew the leaves across the yard." Is that correct?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Yes, it rhymes with find? <break time='400ms'/> You can't tell from the sentence? <break time='400ms'/> No, in this sentence 'wind' rhymes with 'pinned'? <break time='400ms'/> or Both pronunciations work? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Context clue: wind that BLOWS is pronounced like 'pinned,' not like 'find.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The spectators cheered wildly as the runner crossed the finish line.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What are spectators?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Coaches? <break time='400ms'/> People watching? <break time='400ms'/> Runners? <break time='400ms'/> or Judges? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Spectators were cheering ‚Äî they were watching the race, not running it!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The word light can mean many things. What does it mean here?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Please light the candle."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bright? <break time='400ms'/> A shade of color? <break time='400ms'/> To set fire to? <break time='400ms'/> or Not heavy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You 'light' a candle by giving it a flame.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The magician performed an elaborate trick with scarves, rings, and hidden mirrors.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does elaborate mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Simple and quick? <break time='400ms'/> Complex and detailed? <break time='400ms'/> Invisible? <break time='400ms'/> or Boring? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The trick used scarves, rings, AND hidden mirrors ‚Äî that's not simple!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> What does current mean in this sentence?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The strong current carried the boat downstream."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The flow of water? <break time='400ms'/> Happening now? <break time='400ms'/> Electricity? <break time='400ms'/> or A type of fruit? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A current in a river is the moving water that can carry things downstream.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> After the long drought, the parched earth cracked and split.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does parched mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cold? <break time='400ms'/> Wet? <break time='400ms'/> Extremely dry? <break time='400ms'/> or Flat? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A drought means no rain. If the earth is cracking, it must be very dry!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The benevolent king gave food to every poor family in his kingdom.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does benevolent most likely mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Lazy? <break time='400ms'/> Wealthy? <break time='400ms'/> Kind and generous? <break time='400ms'/> or Mean? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A king who gives food to poor families sounds kind and generous!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The abandoned house was empty, with broken windows and weeds growing through the porch.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does abandoned mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Brand new? <break time='400ms'/> Very large? <break time='400ms'/> Recently painted? <break time='400ms'/> or Left behind and empty? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Empty, broken windows, weeds ‚Äî nobody lives there anymore!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The camouflaged lizard blended perfectly with the brown leaves on the ground.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does camouflaged mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Disguised to blend in? <break time='400ms'/> Very large? <break time='400ms'/> Poisonous? <break time='400ms'/> or Brightly colored? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It 'blended perfectly' ‚Äî camouflage means hiding by looking like your surroundings.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The fragile vase shattered into a hundred pieces when it hit the floor.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does fragile mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Expensive? <break time='400ms'/> Strong? <break time='400ms'/> Easily broken? <break time='400ms'/> or Heavy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It shattered into pieces ‚Äî so it must break easily!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The nocturnal owl hunted mice while other birds slept.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Using context clues, nocturnal means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very fast? <break time='400ms'/> Active at night? <break time='400ms'/> Colorful? <break time='400ms'/> or Large and heavy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The owl hunted while other birds SLEPT. When do birds sleep? At night!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If comfort means a state of ease, what does uncomfortable mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Comfortable again? <break time='400ms'/> Very comfortable? <break time='400ms'/> Comfortable before? <break time='400ms'/> or Not comfortable? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Un-' means not. So un + comfortable = not comfortable.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does misspell mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To spell wrongly? <break time='400ms'/> To spell before? <break time='400ms'/> To spell correctly? <break time='400ms'/> or To spell again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Mis-' means wrongly. Mis + spell = spell wrongly!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word impossible means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very possible? <break time='400ms'/> Possible again? <break time='400ms'/> Not possible? <break time='400ms'/> or Possible before? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Im-' (like 'in-') means not. Impossible = not possible.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If courage means bravery, what does encourage mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To take away courage? <break time='400ms'/> To give courage or support to someone? <break time='400ms'/> To be scared? <break time='400ms'/> or To have no courage? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'En-' means to put into. Encourage = put courage INTO someone!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does disappearance mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very visible? <break time='400ms'/> The act of disappearing? <break time='400ms'/> Appearing before? <break time='400ms'/> or Appearing again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Dis + appear + ance. 'Dis-' means opposite, '-ance' means the act of.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If act means to do something, what does action mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The process of doing something? <break time='400ms'/> Not doing anything? <break time='400ms'/> A type of movie? <break time='400ms'/> or Doing something before? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Act + ion. The root 'act' means to do, and '-ion' makes it a noun.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root word port means "to carry." What does transport most likely mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of door? <break time='400ms'/> To carry across or from one place to another? <break time='400ms'/> To stay in one place? <break time='400ms'/> or To drop something? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Trans' means across. 'Port' means carry. Transport = carry across!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You know graph means "to write or draw." Which word is related to writing or drawing?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Grammar? <break time='400ms'/> Giraffe? <break time='400ms'/> Photograph? <break time='400ms'/> or Grape? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Photo = light. Graph = write/draw. A photograph is written with light!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If cycle means circle or wheel, what does bicycle mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> One wheel? <break time='400ms'/> Two wheels? <break time='400ms'/> Three wheels? <break time='400ms'/> or No wheels? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Bi' means two. 'Cycle' means wheel. Bicycle = two wheels!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The words company and companion share the root compan- which means "together with bread." Both words relate to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Traveling alone? <break time='400ms'/> Cooking food? <break time='400ms'/> Being together or having company? <break time='400ms'/> or Baking? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Sharing bread = being together. Both words are about togetherness!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A dictionary entry for bark shows two definitions: 1. The outer covering of a tree. 2. The sound a dog makes.
