How do you know which definition fits?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The bark of the old oak tree was rough and gray."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Use definition 1? <break time='400ms'/> Use definition 2? <break time='400ms'/> Both definitions fit? <break time='400ms'/> or Neither fits? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It's describing a tree, so it's the outer covering ‚Äî definition 1!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Guide words at the top of a dictionary page are maple and "market." Which word would be on this page?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Master? <break time='400ms'/> March? <break time='400ms'/> Magic? <break time='400ms'/> or Magazine? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word must come between 'maple' and 'market' alphabetically.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What information does a dictionary give you about a word?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Only the spelling? <break time='400ms'/> Only example sentences? <break time='400ms'/> Spelling, pronunciation, definition, and part of speech? <break time='400ms'/> or Only the definition? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A dictionary is packed with info ‚Äî spelling, how to say it, what it means, and how to use it!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a glossary, you find: "ecosystem (n.) ‚Äî a community of living things and their environment." The "(n.)" tells you that ecosystem is a ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Verb? <break time='400ms'/> Noun? <break time='400ms'/> Adjective? <break time='400ms'/> or Adverb? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The abbreviation 'n.' stands for noun!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When is it BEST to use a dictionary or glossary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Never ‚Äî just skip unknown words? <break time='400ms'/> When context clues and word parts don't help enough? <break time='400ms'/> When you already know the word? <break time='400ms'/> or Only during tests? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Try context clues first, then word parts. If you're still stuck, grab the dictionary!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> She had a heart of gold.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She was very kind and generous? <break time='400ms'/> Her heart was made of gold metal? <break time='400ms'/> She was rich? <break time='400ms'/> or She wore gold jewelry? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is figurative language ‚Äî a 'heart of gold' means a person who is very kind.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses a simile?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The dog barked loudly.? <break time='400ms'/> The sky was blue.? <break time='400ms'/> He ate his lunch.? <break time='400ms'/> or She was as fast as a rocket.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A simile compares two things using 'as' or 'like.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does break a leg mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Actually break your leg? <break time='400ms'/> Run very fast? <break time='400ms'/> Be careful? <break time='400ms'/> or Good luck? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is an idiom ‚Äî it means the opposite of what it sounds like! Performers say it for luck.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which two words are antonyms (opposites)?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Fast and quick? <break time='400ms'/> Hot and cold? <break time='400ms'/> Happy and joyful? <break time='400ms'/> or Big and large? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Antonyms are opposites. Which pair shows opposite meanings?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The thunder grumbled like an angry old man.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Literal language? <break time='400ms'/> A definition? <break time='400ms'/> A fact? <break time='400ms'/> or Personification and simile? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Thunder 'grumbling' is personification (human action). 'Like an angry old man' is a simile!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Time flies when you're having fun.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Is this literal or nonliteral?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Literal ‚Äî time actually has wings? <break time='400ms'/> Nonliteral ‚Äî it means time seems to pass quickly? <break time='400ms'/> Neither? <break time='400ms'/> or Literal ‚Äî clocks move faster? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Time doesn't actually fly! It's a figurative way of saying time SEEMS to go fast.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence is LITERAL (means exactly what it says)?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The cat sat on the mat.? <break time='400ms'/> He was on cloud nine.? <break time='400ms'/> He's a real couch potato.? <break time='400ms'/> or She has butterflies in her stomach.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Only one of these sentences describes something that could actually, physically happen.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> My backpack weighs a ton.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does this really mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The backpack literally weighs 2,000 pounds? <break time='400ms'/> The backpack feels very heavy? <break time='400ms'/> The backpack is broken? <break time='400ms'/> or The backpack is made of metal? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A backpack can't really weigh a ton! This is an exaggeration (hyperbole).</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> She was drowning in homework.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She fell into a pool of papers? <break time='400ms'/> She had way too much homework? <break time='400ms'/> She needs swimming lessons? <break time='400ms'/> or She was in the ocean? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You can't literally drown in homework! It means she had an overwhelming amount.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> His words cut like a knife.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This sentence means his words were ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Long and boring? <break time='400ms'/> Quiet and soft? <break time='400ms'/> Sharp and hurtful? <break time='400ms'/> or Made of metal? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Words can't actually cut, but they CAN hurt feelings ‚Äî like a knife hurts physically.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When would you describe someone as generous?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> When they are very tall? <break time='400ms'/> When they run fast? <break time='400ms'/> When they keep everything for themselves? <break time='400ms'/> or When they share with others willingly? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Generous means giving freely. Think of someone who shares!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which situation shows cooperation?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Someone sleeping? <break time='400ms'/> A student working alone on a test? <break time='400ms'/> A person eating lunch? <break time='400ms'/> or A group building a fort together? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Cooperation means working together. Which choice shows teamwork?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word BEST describes how you feel when you try something new and scary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Anxious? <break time='400ms'/> Calm? <break time='400ms'/> Bored? <break time='400ms'/> or Sleepy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Trying something new and scary can make you feel nervous or anxious.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A person who always tells the truth can be described as ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Stubborn? <break time='400ms'/> Honest? <break time='400ms'/> Greedy? <break time='400ms'/> or Careless? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Someone truthful is honest ‚Äî a word connected to trust.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word describes a person who keeps trying even when things are difficult?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Forgetful? <break time='400ms'/> Persistent? <break time='400ms'/> Nervous? <break time='400ms'/> or Lazy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think of someone who doesn't give up. They per-sist!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Put these words in order from LEAST certain to MOST certain: knew, suspected, wondered</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Wondered ‚Üí suspected ‚Üí knew? <break time='400ms'/> Knew ‚Üí suspected ‚Üí wondered? <break time='400ms'/> Wondered ‚Üí knew ‚Üí suspected? <break time='400ms'/> or Suspected ‚Üí wondered ‚Üí knew? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Wondering is just curious. Suspecting is thinking it might be true. Knowing is being certain!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word shows the STRONGEST feeling of anger?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bothered? <break time='400ms'/> Furious? <break time='400ms'/> Annoyed? <break time='400ms'/> or Irritated? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! All these words relate to anger, but which one is the most intense?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Put these in order from LEAST scared to MOST scared: terrified, nervous, uneasy</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Nervous ‚Üí uneasy ‚Üí terrified? <break time='400ms'/> Terrified ‚Üí nervous ‚Üí uneasy? <break time='400ms'/> Uneasy ‚Üí nervous ‚Üí terrified? <break time='400ms'/> or Uneasy ‚Üí terrified ‚Üí nervous? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Uneasy is mild, nervous is moderate, terrified is extreme fear!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word means MORE than happy but LESS than ecstatic?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Delighted? <break time='400ms'/> Sad? <break time='400ms'/> Content? <break time='400ms'/> or Okay? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Happy ‚Üí delighted ‚Üí ecstatic. Delighted is in the middle!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> I heard the rumor about the snow day." vs. "I knew school would be canceled.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which shows MORE certainty?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Neither shows certainty? <break time='400ms'/> Both show the same certainty? <break time='400ms'/> 'I heard' shows more certainty? <break time='400ms'/> or 'I knew' shows more certainty? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Hearing something is secondhand information. Knowing is being sure!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses more precise vocabulary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The pasta was delicious and perfectly seasoned.? <break time='400ms'/> I ate stuff? <break time='400ms'/> Lunch was okay? <break time='400ms'/> or The food was good.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Precise words paint a clearer picture. Which sentence tells you the MOST?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In science, habitat means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A science experiment? <break time='400ms'/> The natural home of an animal or plant? <break time='400ms'/> A type of animal? <break time='400ms'/> or A weather pattern? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is a domain-specific word used in science to describe where organisms live.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Which word is a better replacement for said in this sentence?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"'I can't believe it!" ____ Maria."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Whispered? <break time='400ms'/> Said? <break time='400ms'/> Exclaimed? <break time='400ms'/> or Mumbled? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She can't believe it! That shows surprise and excitement. Which word matches that energy?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The academic word compare means to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Draw a picture? <break time='400ms'/> Find how things are alike and different? <break time='400ms'/> Read silently? <break time='400ms'/> or Write a story? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Compare' is a word you use in all subjects ‚Äî it means looking at similarities and differences.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Choose the MOST specific word to complete this sentence:.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The ____ cheetah sprinted across the savanna."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Nice? <break time='400ms'/> Fast? <break time='400ms'/> Quick? <break time='400ms'/> or Swift? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! All could work, but 'swift' is the most vivid and precise for describing a cheetah's speed.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Elena clutched her telescope and crept onto the rooftop. The city lights dimmed the stars, but she knew exactly where to look. At 9:47 PM, a streak of light raced across the sky ‚Äî the comet her grandfather had told her about.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer about Elena's grandfather?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He doesn't like stars? <break time='400ms'/> He shared his knowledge of astronomy with Elena? <break time='400ms'/> He has never seen a comet? <break time='400ms'/> or He lives on the rooftop? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Elena knew exactly where to look because her grandfather told her about the comet.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The letter had been folded and refolded so many times that the creases were soft as fabric. Marcus kept it in his front pocket, close to his chest, even though he'd memorized every word.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer about how Marcus feels about the letter?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He wants to throw it away? <break time='400ms'/> He just received it today? <break time='400ms'/> It's extremely important and meaningful to him? <break time='400ms'/> or He can't read it? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! He keeps it close to his chest and has memorized every word ‚Äî those are signs of deep attachment.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Priya practiced her free throws every morning before school and every evening after dinner. On the day of tryouts, she was the only one who made all ten shots.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What detail from the text BEST supports the idea that hard work pays off?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She practiced before school and after dinner? <break time='400ms'/> She goes to school? <break time='400ms'/> She shoots free throws? <break time='400ms'/> or She went to tryouts? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The detail about her practice schedule directly explains why she succeeded at tryouts.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Dad hadn't said a word during the entire drive home. He gripped the steering wheel tightly, and his jaw was clenched. When they pulled into the driveway, he finally sighed and said, "We'll talk about this inside."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer about Dad's mood?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He's happy and excited? <break time='400ms'/> He's tired from driving? <break time='400ms'/> He's upset or frustrated about something? <break time='400ms'/> or He's hungry? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Silent, tight grip, clenched jaw, deep sigh ‚Äî those are all signs of frustration.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The old bookshop smelled of leather and dust. Mrs. Tanaka knew every book by heart ‚Äî where it sat, what it was about, who had loved it last. When the city announced the building would be torn down, she simply said, "Books always find a new home."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Mrs. Tanaka's response reveal about her character?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She wants a new building? <break time='400ms'/> She's optimistic and resilient even in difficult times? <break time='400ms'/> She doesn't like books? <break time='400ms'/> or She doesn't care about the bookshop? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Instead of being devastated, she focuses on the positive ‚Äî books will survive. That's resilience.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Kai wanted to win the science fair more than anything. He worked alone, refusing help from his classmates. His project looked impressive but had a major flaw he hadn't noticed. Meanwhile, the team next to him ‚Äî who had shared ideas and caught each other's mistakes ‚Äî won first place.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Collaboration leads to better results than working alone? <break time='400ms'/> Working alone is always best? <break time='400ms'/> Science fairs are unfair? <break time='400ms'/> or Winning is everything? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Compare what happened to Kai (alone, missed a flaw) vs. the team (shared ideas, won).</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Amara was embarrassed by her grandmother's accent and old-fashioned clothes. She asked Grandma not to come to the school play. After the show, Amara saw her classmates laughing with their grandparents and felt a deep ache. She called Grandma that night and said, "Next time, front row."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Clothes matter more than people? <break time='400ms'/> Don't be ashamed of your family ‚Äî appreciate them? <break time='400ms'/> Grandparents shouldn't visit schools? <break time='400ms'/> or School plays are boring? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Amara regretted pushing her grandmother away and realized family matters more than appearances.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A theme is different from a topic because ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A theme is always stated directly? <break time='400ms'/> There's no difference? <break time='400ms'/> A theme is one word like 'friendship'? <break time='400ms'/> or A theme is the message or lesson, while a topic is just the subject? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Topic = friendship. Theme = true friends stand by you in hard times.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The tiny seed was carried by the wind past tall trees and mighty oaks. It landed in a crack between two rocks where nothing grew. But the seed pushed through anyway, and years later it became the only tree on that rocky hill.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Seeds need good soil? <break time='400ms'/> Trees are stronger than rocks? <break time='400ms'/> Determination can help you thrive even in difficult conditions? <break time='400ms'/> or Wind is powerful? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The seed grew where 'nothing grew' ‚Äî it succeeded against the odds through persistence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which is the BEST summary of a story?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Just the ending? <break time='400ms'/> A copy of the first paragraph? <break time='400ms'/> A brief retelling of the main character, problem, key events, and resolution? <break time='400ms'/> or A list of every single event that happened? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A good summary hits the highlights: who, what problem, what happened, how it ended.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Coach Reyes never raised her voice. When a player made a mistake, she'd kneel down, look them in the eye, and say, "Tell me what you were thinking." By season's end, every player said she was the best coach they'd ever had.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word BEST describes Coach Reyes?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Strict? <break time='400ms'/> Respectful? <break time='400ms'/> Impatient? <break time='400ms'/> or Careless? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She kneels down, makes eye contact, and asks for their perspective ‚Äî that's deep respect.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The marketplace buzzed with voices in a dozen languages. Spices piled in colorful mountains ‚Äî saffron yellow, paprika red, turmeric orange. Somewhere a radio played scratchy music, and the smell of roasting lamb drifted through the narrow aisles.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author uses these details to create a setting that feels ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Modern and high-tech? <break time='400ms'/> Vibrant, busy, and full of sensory experiences? <break time='400ms'/> Quiet and lonely? <break time='400ms'/> or Cold and frightening? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Voices, colors, music, smells ‚Äî the author hits sight, sound, and smell to bring it alive.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Jordan's hands trembled as he opened the envelope. His eyes scanned the page, then widened. He read it again. Then a third time. Then he let out a whoop so loud the neighbors" dog started barking.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer about the letter's contents?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Bad news? <break time='400ms'/> A grocery list? <break time='400ms'/> Very good news? <break time='400ms'/> or A homework assignment? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Trembling hands (nervous), then widened eyes and a whoop (excitement) ‚Äî that's great news!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When describing a character in depth, you should include ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Their traits, motivations, thoughts, words, and actions? <break time='400ms'/> Just their name and age? <break time='400ms'/> Only what other characters say about them? <break time='400ms'/> or Only what they look like? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A deep character description goes beyond appearance ‚Äî it explores WHO they are inside.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The abandoned lighthouse stood at the edge of the cliff, its paint peeling like sunburned skin. Waves crashed against the rocks below, sending spray twenty feet into the air. Inside, the spiral staircase groaned under the weight of years.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The setting creates a mood that is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Eerie and isolated? <break time='400ms'/> Busy and crowded? <break time='400ms'/> Cheerful and bright? <break time='400ms'/> or Warm and cozy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Abandoned, peeling paint, crashing waves, groaning staircase ‚Äî all create a lonely, spooky mood.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> She had the Midas touch ‚Äî every business she started turned into gold.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This allusion to King Midas means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She was a queen? <break time='400ms'/> Everything she did became successful? <break time='400ms'/> She was greedy? <break time='400ms'/> or She literally turned things to gold? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! King Midas turned everything to gold. This phrase means everything she touches succeeds.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Cleaning out the garage was a Herculean task.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This allusion to Hercules means the task was ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Extremely difficult and required great effort? <break time='400ms'/> Impossible to start? <break time='400ms'/> Easy and quick? <break time='400ms'/> or Fun and entertaining? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Hercules was famous for completing incredibly difficult tasks (his twelve labors).</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The morning light tiptoed through the curtains.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does tiptoed suggest about the light?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It was nighttime? <break time='400ms'/> It was very bright and harsh? <break time='400ms'/> It entered gently and softly? <break time='400ms'/> or The curtains were open? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Tiptoeing is quiet and careful ‚Äî the light came in softly, not harshly.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> His Achilles" heel was his temper ‚Äî it always got him into trouble.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>An Achilles heel" refers to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of shoe? <break time='400ms'/> A person's greatest weakness or vulnerability? <break time='400ms'/> A battle strategy? <break time='400ms'/> or A foot injury? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! In mythology, Achilles was invincible except for his heel. The phrase means a fatal weakness.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The silence in the library was so thick you could cut it with a knife.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This phrase means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> People were cooking in the library? <break time='400ms'/> Someone had a knife in the library? <break time='400ms'/> The silence was intense and heavy? <break time='400ms'/> or The library was noisy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! This is figurative ‚Äî the silence felt so strong and present it was almost physical.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which structural element is found in a drama (play) but NOT in prose (a regular story)?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Chapters? <break time='400ms'/> Paragraphs? <break time='400ms'/> A title? <break time='400ms'/> or Stage directions? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Stage directions (in italics or brackets) tell actors how to move and speak ‚Äî only plays have these.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A poem is organized into stanzas. Stanzas are similar to ____ in prose.</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Sentences? <break time='400ms'/> Titles? <break time='400ms'/> Paragraphs? <break time='400ms'/> or Chapters? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Stanzas group lines in a poem, just like paragraphs group sentences in prose.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How is dialogue presented differently in a play versus a novel?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> In plays, the character's name appears before their lines; novels use quotation marks? <break time='400ms'/> Novels don't have dialogue? <break time='400ms'/> There's no difference? <break time='400ms'/> or Plays don't have dialogue? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Play: ROMEO: But soft! Novel: "But soft!" said Romeo.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What structural element do poems often have that prose does not?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A beginning and end? <break time='400ms'/> Characters? <break time='400ms'/> Meter and rhyme scheme? <break time='400ms'/> or Sentences? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Poems often have rhythm (meter) and patterns of rhyming ‚Äî prose usually doesn't.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A verse in a poem is most similar to a ____ in a novel.</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Chapter? <break time='400ms'/> Setting? <break time='400ms'/> Line or sentence? <break time='400ms'/> or Character? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A verse is a single line of poetry ‚Äî similar to how a sentence is a unit in prose.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> I couldn't believe my eyes when I opened the door.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is written in ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> No point of view? <break time='400ms'/> First person? <break time='400ms'/> Third person? <break time='400ms'/> or Second person? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'I' is the key clue ‚Äî the narrator is telling their own story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Sarah couldn't believe her eyes when she opened the door.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is written in ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Second person? <break time='400ms'/> Third person? <break time='400ms'/> First person? <break time='400ms'/> or No point of view? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The narrator uses 'she' and 'Sarah' ‚Äî someone else is telling Sarah's story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does first-person narration affect a story compared to third-person?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> There's no difference? <break time='400ms'/> Third person is always more honest? <break time='400ms'/> First person gives you access to every character's thoughts? <break time='400ms'/> or First person limits you to one character's perspective and feelings? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! With 'I,' you only know what THAT character knows and feels.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A story told by an outside narrator who knows the thoughts and feelings of ALL characters is called ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> First person? <break time='400ms'/> Second person? <break time='400ms'/> Third person omniscient? <break time='400ms'/> or Third person limited? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Omniscient' means all-knowing ‚Äî this narrator can see into everyone's mind.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The same event is described two ways: Version A: "I scored the winning goal and felt like a hero." Version B: "Jake scored the winning goal. His teammates cheered, but the other team walked away in silence."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does the point of view change what the reader learns?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Version A shows Jake's feelings; Version B shows both teams' reactions? <break time='400ms'/> Version B is better written? <break time='400ms'/> Both versions give the same information? <break time='400ms'/> or Version A has more details? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! First person (A) gives inner feelings. Third person (B) gives a wider view of the scene.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A student reads a chapter about a thunderstorm, then watches a movie version with dramatic music and dark lighting. The movie version adds ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> New characters? <break time='400ms'/> Mood and atmosphere through sound and visuals? <break time='400ms'/> A different ending? <break time='400ms'/> or More dialogue? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Music and lighting create feelings that words alone describe differently.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When a book is turned into a play, what might be LOST?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> All the characters? <break time='400ms'/> The character's inner thoughts described by the narrator? <break time='400ms'/> The plot? <break time='400ms'/> or Dialogue? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! On stage, you can't hear what a character is thinking the way a narrator can tell you.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What might a visual presentation (movie or play) ADD to a story that the text cannot?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> More chapters? <break time='400ms'/> More words? <break time='400ms'/> Longer descriptions? <break time='400ms'/> or Facial expressions, tone of voice, and body language of actors? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Actors bring characters to life with their faces, voices, and movements.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A book describes a character as "a tall woman with kind eyes." In the movie, the actress has a warm smile and speaks softly. How does the movie expand on the text?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It contradicts the book? <break time='400ms'/> It shows specific visual and audio details that bring 'kind eyes' to life? <break time='400ms'/> It removes the description? <break time='400ms'/> or It changes the character completely? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The movie translates 'kind eyes' into a warm smile and soft voice ‚Äî making it real.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why might a reader prefer the book version over the movie?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Movies don't have stories? <break time='400ms'/> The reader's imagination creates a personal version of the story? <break time='400ms'/> Books have more special effects? <break time='400ms'/> or Books are always better? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! When you read, YOU decide what characters look like and how settings feel.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A Greek myth says the sun is pulled across the sky by the god Helios in a chariot. A Native American story says the sun is carried by a spirit eagle. Both stories try to explain ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Why birds can fly? <break time='400ms'/> How the sun moves across the sky? <break time='400ms'/> Why it rains? <break time='400ms'/> or How fire was created? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both cultures created stories to explain the same natural phenomenon ‚Äî the sun's movement.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Many cultures have flood myths ‚Äî a great flood that covers the earth. What does this SIMILARITY suggest?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They all copied from one story? <break time='400ms'/> Only one culture had a flood? <break time='400ms'/> Ancient peoples around the world may have experienced similar natural disasters? <break time='400ms'/> or Floods never actually happened? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! When many cultures tell similar stories, it often reflects shared human experiences.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A European fairy tale and a West African folktale both feature a clever trickster who outsmarts a more powerful character. The European version uses a fox; the African version uses a spider named Anansi. What is the SAME?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The animal character? <break time='400ms'/> The language? <break time='400ms'/> The setting? <break time='400ms'/> or The theme of cleverness defeating power? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Different characters, same message ‚Äî brains can beat brawn.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why do different cultures often tell stories with similar themes?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Human experiences like love, courage, and fairness are universal? <break time='400ms'/> They all speak the same language? <break time='400ms'/> They don't have any different themes? <break time='400ms'/> or One culture wrote all the stories? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! People everywhere face similar challenges and value similar things.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When comparing myths from different cultures, the MOST important thing to examine is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How long each myth is? <break time='400ms'/> How each culture uses its own characters and settings to explore universal themes? <break time='400ms'/> Which myth is more exciting? <break time='400ms'/> or Which myth is older? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The richest comparison looks at how different cultures express the same big ideas.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Nobody knew where the music came from. Every night at midnight, a violin played from somewhere deep in the woods. The townspeople locked their doors and whispered about ghosts. Only young Alma grabbed her lantern and followed the sound.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Alma's action reveal about her?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She plays violin? <break time='400ms'/> She's foolish and doesn't listen? <break time='400ms'/> She's curious and braver than the other townspeople? <break time='400ms'/> or She's a ghost? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! While everyone else locked their doors in fear, Alma went TOWARD the mystery.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The treaty was signed on a Tuesday. By Wednesday, the two kingdoms had already broken it. Peace, the old queen muttered, "is harder to keep than to promise."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the queen's message about peace?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Making peace is simple but maintaining it is the real challenge? <break time='400ms'/> Tuesdays are unlucky? <break time='400ms'/> Treaties always work? <break time='400ms'/> or Peace is easy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! They signed peace easily but broke it immediately ‚Äî keeping peace is the hard part.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theo didn't notice the first leaf fall. Or the second. But by the time the maple tree was half bare, he understood what his grandmother meant when she said, "Change happens slowly, then all at once."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is Grandmother's saying about?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How change in life can be gradual then suddenly obvious? <break time='400ms'/> Maple trees grow fast? <break time='400ms'/> Only about trees losing leaves? <break time='400ms'/> or Autumn is the best season? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The leaves are a metaphor ‚Äî change builds quietly until suddenly you notice everything is different.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Zuri had two rules: never break a promise, and always carry a pencil. You never know, she said, "when you'll need to write something down before you forget it ‚Äî or before someone tries to make you forget."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the second rule suggest about Zuri?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She forgets everything? <break time='400ms'/> She's a teacher? <break time='400ms'/> She likes drawing? <break time='400ms'/> or She values truth and recording important things? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She writes things down so they can't be changed or forgotten ‚Äî she values accuracy and truth.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The ship had been at sea for thirty-seven days. Fresh water was running low, and the crew whispered about turning back. Captain Adaeze stood at the bow, eyes fixed on the horizon. Land by sunrise, she said. Nobody believed her. But at dawn, there it was.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What theme does this passage suggest?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ships are dangerous? <break time='400ms'/> The ocean is beautiful? <break time='400ms'/> Faith and determination can lead you through doubt? <break time='400ms'/> or Captains are always right? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Everyone doubted, but the captain held firm ‚Äî and she was right.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The International Space Station orbits Earth at approximately 17,500 miles per hour. At this speed, astronauts experience 16 sunrises and 16 sunsets every 24 hours.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What detail explains why astronauts see so many sunrises?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It orbits at 17,500 mph, completing an orbit roughly every 90 minutes? <break time='400ms'/> Astronauts sleep less? <break time='400ms'/> The sun moves faster in space? <break time='400ms'/> or The station is large? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The extreme speed means it circles Earth many times a day ‚Äî each orbit brings a new sunrise.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Jane Goodall arrived in Tanzania in 1960 with no formal training in science. Within months, she observed chimpanzees using sticks as tools to extract termites ‚Äî a discovery that changed our understanding of what makes humans unique.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What inference can you make about why this discovery was so important?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Tanzania is a new country? <break time='400ms'/> Scientists previously believed only humans used tools? <break time='400ms'/> People didn't know about termites before? <break time='400ms'/> or Chimpanzees are smarter than humans? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text says it 'changed our understanding of what makes humans unique' ‚Äî tool use was thought to be a human-only ability.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Honeybees communicate through a "waggle dance." A bee returning from a food source dances in a figure-eight pattern. The angle of the dance indicates the direction of the food relative to the sun.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What specific detail tells you HOW bees show direction?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They fly in a straight line? <break time='400ms'/> The angle of the dance relative to the sun? <break time='400ms'/> They make buzzing sounds? <break time='400ms'/> or They dance in a circle? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The last sentence gives the precise detail about direction.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> During the California Gold Rush of 1849, most miners didn't get rich from gold. However, merchants who sold pickaxes, shovels, and jeans to the miners made fortunes.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What can you infer from this passage?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Selling supplies to miners was more profitable than mining itself? <break time='400ms'/> The Gold Rush lasted one year? <break time='400ms'/> Merchants also mined for gold? <break time='400ms'/> or Gold was easy to find? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Most miners didn't get rich, but the people selling them tools did ‚Äî what does that tell you?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When you draw an inference from a text, you ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Only read the title? <break time='400ms'/> Copy a sentence from the text? <break time='400ms'/> Draw a picture of the text? <break time='400ms'/> or Use clues from the text plus your own knowledge to figure something out? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An inference = text evidence + your brain. You figure out what the author implies but doesn't directly say.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Plastic pollution is devastating ocean ecosystems. Over 8 million tons of plastic enter the oceans each year. Sea turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish. Microplastics have been found in fish that humans eat.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main idea?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Plastic pollution is seriously harming ocean life? <break time='400ms'/> Sea turtles eat jellyfish? <break time='400ms'/> 8 million tons is a lot? <break time='400ms'/> or Fish contain microplastics? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence states the main idea. Every other sentence supports it with examples.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Ancient Rome's road system was an engineering marvel. Roman roads were built in layers ‚Äî gravel, sand, and paving stones ‚Äî designed to last centuries. Over 250,000 miles of roads connected the empire. Many of these roads are still visible today.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which detail BEST supports the main idea that Roman roads were remarkable?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Many roads are still visible centuries later? <break time='400ms'/> Roads were made of gravel? <break time='400ms'/> Rome had an empire? <break time='400ms'/> or Roads connected cities? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Roads lasting CENTURIES is the most powerful evidence of their remarkable quality.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A good summary of an informational text includes ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The main idea and the most important supporting details in your own words? <break time='400ms'/> Just the title and author? <break time='400ms'/> Only your personal opinion? <break time='400ms'/> or Every single detail from the text? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Summaries are brief ‚Äî main idea + key details, in YOUR words, no small details.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Exercise benefits the brain in multiple ways. Physical activity increases blood flow to the brain, delivering more oxygen. It also triggers the release of chemicals that improve mood and focus. Studies show students who exercise regularly perform better academically.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does the detail about students support the main idea?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It provides real-world evidence that exercise helps brains work better? <break time='400ms'/> It's about schools, not brains? <break time='400ms'/> It contradicts the main idea? <break time='400ms'/> or It changes the topic? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Better academic performance = proof that exercise benefits the brain. It's concrete evidence!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Paragraph 1: Renewable energy sources like solar and wind are growing rapidly. Paragraph 2: Solar panel costs have dropped 89% since 2010. Paragraph 3: Wind energy now powers millions of homes.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The main idea of the ENTIRE passage is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Energy is expensive? <break time='400ms'/> Wind energy is popular? <break time='400ms'/> Solar panels are cheap? <break time='400ms'/> or Renewable energy is growing and becoming more accessible? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Both paragraphs 2 and 3 give specific examples supporting the big idea in paragraph 1.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In 1773, American colonists were furious about being taxed by Britain without representation in Parliament. A group of colonists disguised as Native Americans boarded British ships and dumped 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What caused the Boston Tea Party?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The ships were blocking the harbor? <break time='400ms'/> The colonists wanted free tea? <break time='400ms'/> Britain declared war? <break time='400ms'/> or Anger over taxation without representation? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The first sentence states the cause ‚Äî being taxed without having a voice in government.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Vaccines work by introducing a weakened or inactive form of a virus to the body. The immune system learns to recognize and fight the virus. If the person is later exposed to the real virus, their body already knows how to defeat it.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Explain the SEQUENCE of how vaccines work:</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Real virus enters ‚Üí immune system fights ‚Üí vaccine given? <break time='400ms'/> Vaccine introduces weak virus ‚Üí immune system learns to fight it ‚Üí body is prepared for the real virus? <break time='400ms'/> Body gets sick ‚Üí takes medicine ‚Üí feels better? <break time='400ms'/> or Immune system attacks ‚Üí virus enters ‚Üí vaccine helps? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Follow the order: introduce weak virus first, then the body learns, then it's ready.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The invention of the printing press in 1440 made books affordable for the first time. Before that, books were copied by hand, making them rare and expensive. As books became accessible, literacy rates soared across Europe.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What was the EFFECT of the printing press on literacy?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Literacy rates soared because books became accessible? <break time='400ms'/> Literacy decreased? <break time='400ms'/> Nothing changed? <break time='400ms'/> or People stopped reading? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Affordable books ‚Üí more people could get books ‚Üí more people learned to read.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Photosynthesis occurs in the leaves of plants. Chlorophyll in the leaves absorbs sunlight. The plant combines this energy with water from the roots and carbon dioxide from the air to produce glucose and oxygen.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What are the INPUTS (ingredients) of photosynthesis?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Glucose and oxygen? <break time='400ms'/> Only sunlight? <break time='400ms'/> Roots and leaves? <break time='400ms'/> or Sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The plant combines sunlight + water + CO2 to MAKE glucose and oxygen.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When explaining a historical event, it's important to include ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> What happened, why it happened, and what resulted from it? <break time='400ms'/> Just the people involved? <break time='400ms'/> Only your opinion about it? <break time='400ms'/> or Only the date? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A complete explanation covers the event, its causes, and its effects.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The archaeologist carefully excavated the site, removing layers of dirt to reveal ancient pottery buried for thousands of years.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does excavated mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Covered up? <break time='400ms'/> Photographed? <break time='400ms'/> Dug up carefully? <break time='400ms'/> or Destroyed? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She's removing layers of dirt to reveal things ‚Äî that's careful digging.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The legislative branch of government is responsible for making laws. Congress, made up of the Senate and House of Representatives, is the legislative branch.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does legislative relate to?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Breaking laws? <break time='400ms'/> Making laws? <break time='400ms'/> Interpreting laws? <break time='400ms'/> or Enforcing laws? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text defines it directly ‚Äî the legislative branch MAKES laws.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The ecosystem was thriving ‚Äî diverse species of plants and animals coexisted in a balanced, interdependent community.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does interdependent mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Fighting each other? <break time='400ms'/> Independent? <break time='400ms'/> Depending on each other? <break time='400ms'/> or Living alone? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Inter' means between/among. 'Dependent' means relying on. Together = relying on each other.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a butterfly involves a complete transformation of the insect's body.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does metamorphosis mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of butterfly? <break time='400ms'/> A cocoon? <break time='400ms'/> A type of insect? <break time='400ms'/> or A dramatic change in form? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text says 'complete transformation' right after ‚Äî that defines metamorphosis!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The drought caused widespread famine. Crops withered in the fields, and livestock had no grass to eat. Thousands of people faced severe hunger.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does famine mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Extreme widespread hunger? <break time='400ms'/> Hot weather? <break time='400ms'/> A farming technique? <break time='400ms'/> or A type of storm? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Crops died, animals starved, thousands faced severe hunger ‚Äî famine means extreme hunger on a large scale.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A passage first describes a problem (too much trash in the ocean) and then explains ways to fix it (recycling programs, beach cleanups). This text structure is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Problem and solution? <break time='400ms'/> Chronological order? <break time='400ms'/> Cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> or Compare and contrast? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Problem presented ‚Üí solution offered. Classic problem/solution structure!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Signal words like "first, next, then, finally" indicate which text structure?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> Chronologicalsequential order? <break time='400ms'/> Compare and contrast? <break time='400ms'/> or Description? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! These words show ORDER ‚Äî things happening in sequence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A passage about hurricanes and tornadoes uses words like similarly, "however," and "on the other hand." This structure is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> Compare and contrast? <break time='400ms'/> Chronological order? <break time='400ms'/> or Problem and solution? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Similarly' shows likeness; 'however' and 'on the other hand' show differences.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Because the temperature dropped below freezing, the pipes burst. As a result, the basement flooded.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Cause and effect? <break time='400ms'/> Compare and contrast? <break time='400ms'/> Description? <break time='400ms'/> or Problem and solution? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Because' and 'as a result' are cause-and-effect signal words.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is it helpful to identify a text's structure?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It helps you understand how the author organized ideas and find information more easily? <break time='400ms'/> It makes the text shorter? <break time='400ms'/> It's only important for fiction? <break time='400ms'/> or It changes the meaning of the text? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Knowing the structure is like having a map ‚Äî it helps you navigate the text.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A firsthand account is written by someone who ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Heard about it from a friend? <break time='400ms'/> Was actually there and experienced it? <break time='400ms'/> Read about the event in a book? <break time='400ms'/> or Watched a documentary about it? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Firsthand = first person = 'I was there.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which is a firsthand account?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A soldier's diary from the Civil War battlefield? <break time='400ms'/> A textbook chapter about the Civil War? <break time='400ms'/> A Wikipedia article about a battle? <break time='400ms'/> or A movie about the war? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The soldier was THERE. Everyone else is writing about it secondhand.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How might a firsthand account DIFFER from a secondhand account of the same event?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Firsthand accounts include personal feelings and experiences; secondhand accounts are more objective? <break time='400ms'/> Secondhand accounts have more feelings? <break time='400ms'/> They're always exactly the same? <break time='400ms'/> or Firsthand accounts are always shorter? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Being there means emotions and personal details. Writing about it later means more distance and objectivity.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Account A: "I could feel the ground shaking under my feet. Dust filled the air and I couldn't see." Account B: "The earthquake measured 6.7 on the Richter scale and caused significant structural damage."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which is firsthand?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Account B? <break time='400ms'/> Account A? <break time='400ms'/> Both? <break time='400ms'/> or Neither? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Account A uses 'I' and describes personal sensory experiences. That's firsthand!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is it valuable to read BOTH firsthand and secondhand accounts?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Firsthand gives personal perspective; secondhand gives broader context ‚Äî together you get a fuller picture? <break time='400ms'/> Firsthand is always more accurate? <break time='400ms'/> Secondhand is always more accurate? <break time='400ms'/> or You only need one type? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Each type offers something the other can't. Together, they give you the complete story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A bar graph shows that the school recycled 200 pounds in January, 350 in February, and 500 in March. What trend does the graph show?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Recycling increased each month? <break time='400ms'/> The school stopped recycling? <break time='400ms'/> Recycling decreased each month? <break time='400ms'/> or Recycling stayed the same? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 200 ‚Üí 350 ‚Üí 500. The numbers are going UP each month.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A timeline in a history text shows events from 1760 to 1790. This visual helps readers ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Learn about geography? <break time='400ms'/> Understand the exact words people said? <break time='400ms'/> Read faster? <break time='400ms'/> or See the sequence and spacing of events over time? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Timelines show WHEN things happened and how much time passed between events.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A pie chart shows: 45% of students prefer pizza, 30% prefer tacos, 15% prefer pasta, 10% prefer salad. What can you conclude?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Salad is the most popular? <break time='400ms'/> Tacos and pizza are equally popular? <break time='400ms'/> Everyone likes pizza? <break time='400ms'/> or Pizza is the most popular but not everyone's favorite? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 45% is the biggest slice, but that means 55% prefer something else!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:
