script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does a diagram of the human digestive system help a reader MORE than a written description alone?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It adds color to the page? <break time='400ms'/> It shows the physical layout and connections between organs that are hard to describe in words? <break time='400ms'/> It replaces the need to read? <break time='400ms'/> or It makes the text longer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Seeing WHERE organs are and how they connect is much easier in a picture than in words.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When interpreting a graph, the FIRST thing you should look at is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The colors? <break time='400ms'/> The title and axis labels to understand what data is being shown? <break time='400ms'/> The source at the bottom? <break time='400ms'/> or The smallest bar? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Before reading the data, you need to know WHAT the graph is measuring!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Schools should offer more art classes. Studies show that students in art programs score higher on standardized tests. Art also teaches creativity, problem-solving, and collaboration.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>The author supports their point with ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> No evidence? <break time='400ms'/> Research studies and specific skills art teaches? <break time='400ms'/> Personal opinions only? <break time='400ms'/> or A story about an artist? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author uses data (test scores) AND specific benefits (creativity, problem-solving) as evidence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which type of evidence is STRONGEST?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 'Recess is fun'? <break time='400ms'/> 'Everybody knows recess matters'? <break time='400ms'/> 'I think recess is important'? <break time='400ms'/> or 'Studies show students who have recess perform 20% better on afternoon tests'? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Specific data from studies is stronger than opinions or vague claims.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Endangered species need stronger legal protections. The bald eagle was nearly extinct until the Endangered Species Act helped its population recover from 417 pairs in 1963 to over 316,000 today.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does the bald eagle example support the author's point?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It changes the topic to birds? <break time='400ms'/> It shows eagles are pretty? <break time='400ms'/> It proves that legal protections actually work to save species? <break time='400ms'/> or It's just an interesting fact? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author's point is that protections are needed. The eagle example PROVES they work.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When evaluating an author's argument, you should ask ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Does the evidence actually support the point being made?? <break time='400ms'/> Does it have pictures?? <break time='400ms'/> Is the text long enough?? <break time='400ms'/> or Is the author famous?? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Critical readers check whether the evidence truly connects to and proves the author's claim.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>An author argues that school lunches should be healthier. Which evidence would NOT support this point?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Students who eat nutritious lunches concentrate better? <break time='400ms'/> Childhood obesity rates are rising? <break time='400ms'/> Processed foods are linked to health problems? <break time='400ms'/> or The cafeteria was painted blue last year? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The paint color has nothing to do with how healthy the food is ‚Äî it's irrelevant evidence.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A explains how solar panels convert sunlight to electricity. Text B discusses the environmental benefits of solar energy. To write a complete report on solar energy, you should ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ignore both and use your own knowledge? <break time='400ms'/> Only use Text A? <break time='400ms'/> Combine information from both texts? <break time='400ms'/> or Only use Text B? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Each text contributes different pieces. Together, they give you a complete picture.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Text A: "Mars has a thin atmosphere made mostly of carbon dioxide." Text B: "Mars has massive dust storms that can cover the entire planet for months."<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Using both texts, what can you explain about Mars?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Both its atmospheric composition AND its extreme weather patterns? <break time='400ms'/> Only its atmosphere? <break time='400ms'/> Nothing new? <break time='400ms'/> or Only its weather? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Text A gives atmosphere facts. Text B gives weather facts. Together = a fuller picture of Mars.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When integrating information from two sources, what should you watch for?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Whether the sources agree, disagree, or provide complementary information? <break time='400ms'/> Which text has better pictures? <break time='400ms'/> Which text is longer? <break time='400ms'/> or Which was written first? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good researchers note when sources support each other, contradict each other, or fill in different gaps.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Text A says wolves were removed from Yellowstone in the 1920s. Text B says after wolves were reintroduced in 1995, the elk population became healthier and rivers changed course. Combining these texts helps you understand ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The long-term impact of removing and then restoring a species to an ecosystem? <break time='400ms'/> Wolves are dangerous? <break time='400ms'/> 1995 was an important year? <break time='400ms'/> or Rivers always change course? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Text A = removal. Text B = reintroduction and effects. Together = the full cause-and-effect story.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is using multiple sources better than using just one?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Multiple sources provide different perspectives, details, and a more complete understanding? <break time='400ms'/> One source always has errors? <break time='400ms'/> You should always use exactly one source? <break time='400ms'/> or More sources means a longer report? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Each source might cover different angles or details. Together, your understanding is richer.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The human brain weighs about three pounds but uses roughly 20% of the body's total energy. It contains approximately 86 billion neurons, each connected to thousands of others, forming a network more complex than any computer ever built.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What comparison does the author make to emphasize the brain's complexity?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Comparing it to the heart? <break time='400ms'/> Comparing it to a muscle? <break time='400ms'/> Comparing it to other organs? <break time='400ms'/> or Comparing it to a computer? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The author says the brain's network is 'more complex than any computer ever built.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Dead Sea, located between Israel and Jordan, is nearly ten times saltier than the ocean. This extreme salinity means no fish or plants can survive in it ‚Äî hence the name. However, the mineral-rich mud and water have been used for health treatments for thousands of years.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is ironic about the Dead Sea?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It's between two countries? <break time='400ms'/> It's very salty? <break time='400ms'/> It's not really a sea? <break time='400ms'/> or Despite being called 'dead,' it has been valuable for human health for millennia? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Called 'dead' because nothing lives in it ‚Äî yet it HELPS living humans. That's ironic!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> In 1983, Dr. Sally Ride became the first American woman in space. She later founded Sally Ride Science, an organization encouraging girls to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and math.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does this tell you about Dr. Ride's priorities?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She only cared about her own career? <break time='400ms'/> She wanted to inspire the next generation, especially girls, to follow in her footsteps? <break time='400ms'/> She stopped working after 1983? <break time='400ms'/> or She didn't like science? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She founded an organization specifically to encourage girls in STEM ‚Äî that shows her priorities.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Bamboo is one of the fastest-growing plants on Earth, capable of growing up to 35 inches in a single day. It's also incredibly strong ‚Äî pound for pound, bamboo has a greater tensile strength than steel.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why might bamboo be considered a super-plant?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It grows extremely fast AND is stronger than steel by weight? <break time='400ms'/> It's green? <break time='400ms'/> It grows in Asia? <break time='400ms'/> or It's a type of tree? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Two extraordinary qualities: incredible growth speed AND incredible strength.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The Library of Alexandria, built around 300 BCE in Egypt, was the ancient world's greatest center of learning. Scholars from across the Mediterranean came to study its estimated 400,000 scrolls. When it was eventually destroyed, countless works of ancient knowledge were lost forever.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What makes the Library's destruction significant?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Libraries are expensive to build? <break time='400ms'/> It had too many scrolls? <break time='400ms'/> Irreplaceable knowledge accumulated over centuries was permanently lost? <break time='400ms'/> or It was in Egypt? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 400,000 scrolls of ancient knowledge ‚Äî gone forever. That's a massive loss to human history.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word autobiography can be broken into: auto + bio + graph + y. Using these parts, what does it mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A life story written by the person themselves? <break time='400ms'/> A book about cars? <break time='400ms'/> A drawing of a machine? <break time='400ms'/> or A type of photograph? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Auto = self, bio = life, graph = write. Self + life + write = writing about your own life!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word contains the Greek root tele meaning far?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Telescope? <break time='400ms'/> Telephone? <break time='400ms'/> All of the above? <break time='400ms'/> or Television? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Tele = far. Phone = sound. Vision = seeing. Scope = viewing. All involve far-distance!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in the word communication?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 5? <break time='400ms'/> 4? <break time='400ms'/> 6? <break time='400ms'/> or 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Clap it: com-mu-ni-ca-tion. Five beats!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In the word unbreakable, the prefix, root, and suffix are ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Un + break + able? <break time='400ms'/> Un + brea + kable? <break time='400ms'/> Unbreak + able? <break time='400ms'/> or Unb + reak + able? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Un- (not) + break (root) + -able (can be done) = cannot be broken.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word pseudonym uses the Greek root pseudo meaning false and nym meaning "name." A pseudonym is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of poem? <break time='400ms'/> A false or fake name used by an author? <break time='400ms'/> A dictionary entry? <break time='400ms'/> or A real name? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! False + name = a fake name. Authors like Mark Twain used pseudonyms!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You encounter the unfamiliar word "transportation." What's the BEST first step?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ask someone immediately? <break time='400ms'/> Break it into parts: trans + port + a + tion? <break time='400ms'/> Guess from the first letter? <break time='400ms'/> or Skip it? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Breaking big words into smaller, recognizable parts makes them manageable!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The word international can be decoded as ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Inter + nat + ional? <break time='400ms'/> In + tern + at + ional? <break time='400ms'/> In + ter + nation + al? <break time='400ms'/> or Interna + tional? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Inter (between) + nation + al (relating to) = between nations.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If you know that -ology means study of, what does biology study?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rocks? <break time='400ms'/> Stars? <break time='400ms'/> Weather? <break time='400ms'/> or Living things (bio = life)? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Bio = life. -ology = study of. Biology = study of life!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How many syllables are in extraordinary?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> 6? <break time='400ms'/> 5? <break time='400ms'/> 7? <break time='400ms'/> or 4? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! ex-tra-or-di-na-ry. Count each vowel sound!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You see the word misconception for the first time. Using morphology, what does it mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of puzzle? <break time='400ms'/> A new concept? <break time='400ms'/> A wrong or mistaken belief? <break time='400ms'/> or A correct idea? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Mis (wrong) + concept (idea) + ion (state of) = a wrong idea or mistaken belief.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A fluent reader adjusts their reading speed based on ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> What time it is? <break time='400ms'/> How many people are listening? <break time='400ms'/> How many pages are left? <break time='400ms'/> or The difficulty and type of text they're reading? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You'd read a science textbook slower than a fun novel. Good readers adjust!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why is reading fluency important for comprehension?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> When you read smoothly, your brain can focus on understanding instead of struggling with words? <break time='400ms'/> Fluent readers skip more words? <break time='400ms'/> Fluency only matters for reading aloud? <break time='400ms'/> or It's not important? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If you're stuck on every word, you can't focus on meaning. Fluency frees your brain to think.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When reading a passage with technical vocabulary, a good reader should ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Speed up to get through it faster? <break time='400ms'/> Stop reading? <break time='400ms'/> Skip the technical words? <break time='400ms'/> or Slow down and use context clues to understand unfamiliar terms? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Hard vocabulary = slow down, not speed up. Use context to figure out the meaning.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which shows the BEST reading fluency?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Skipping every other word to read faster? <break time='400ms'/> ReadingsoFASSthatnobodycanunderstand? <break time='400ms'/> Reading... each... word... one... at... a... time...? <break time='400ms'/> or Reading smoothly with natural pauses at commas and periods, and expression that matches the content? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Fluent reading flows naturally ‚Äî not too choppy, not too rushed.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Self-monitoring while reading means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Checking your own understanding as you read and going back when something doesn't make sense? <break time='400ms'/> Reading out loud? <break time='400ms'/> Having someone else check your reading? <break time='400ms'/> or Timing how fast you read? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Good readers constantly ask themselves 'Does this make sense?' as they read.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The company decided to table the discussion until next week's meeting.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>In this sentence, table means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To organize neatly? <break time='400ms'/> To postpone or delay? <break time='400ms'/> A piece of furniture? <break time='400ms'/> or To serve food? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'Table the discussion until next week' ‚Äî they're putting it aside for later.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> After the long hike, the exhausted climbers sought refuge in a mountain cabin.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does refuge mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A safe place or shelter? <break time='400ms'/> A type of mountain? <break time='400ms'/> Food? <break time='400ms'/> or A dangerous path? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! They were exhausted and needed somewhere safe to rest ‚Äî a shelter.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The word scale has many meanings. What does it mean here?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The fish's scale shimmered in the sunlight."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A thin plate covering a fish's body? <break time='400ms'/> To climb? <break time='400ms'/> A weighing device? <break time='400ms'/> or A musical sequence? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Context: it's on a fish and it shimmers. That's the thin, shiny covering!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The philanthropist donated millions to build schools in underserved communities.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>Using the Greek roots phil (love) and anthrop (human), a philanthropist is someone who ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Collects stamps? <break time='400ms'/> Loves helping humanity through generous donations? <break time='400ms'/> Studies philosophy? <break time='400ms'/> or Teaches at a school? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Phil = love + anthrop = human. A lover of humanity who helps through generosity!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When you encounter a word with multiple meanings, the BEST way to determine which meaning is correct is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Use the surrounding context to figure out which meaning fits? <break time='400ms'/> Pick the easiest definition? <break time='400ms'/> Always use the first definition in the dictionary? <break time='400ms'/> or Ask someone else? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The words around a multiple-meaning word tell you which definition the author intended.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The unprecedented snowstorm shut down the entire city ‚Äî nothing like it had ever happened before.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does unprecedented mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Never happened before? <break time='400ms'/> Very cold? <break time='400ms'/> Predicted by scientists? <break time='400ms'/> or Expected? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The text literally says 'nothing like it had ever happened before' ‚Äî that defines unprecedented!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The resilient community rebuilt their homes after the hurricane, stronger than before.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does resilient mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Able to recover and bounce back? <break time='400ms'/> Moving to a new place? <break time='400ms'/> Angry and upset? <break time='400ms'/> or Weak and defeated? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! They rebuilt stronger than before ‚Äî that's bouncing back from difficulty!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Her meticulous notes included every detail ‚Äî dates, names, page numbers, and color-coded tabs.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does meticulous mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Messy and disorganized? <break time='400ms'/> Simple and basic? <break time='400ms'/> Quick and careless? <break time='400ms'/> or Extremely careful and thorough? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Every detail, color-coded tabs ‚Äî that's extremely thorough and careful work!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The two countries formed an alliance, agreeing to protect each other in times of war.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>An alliance is ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A type of weapon? <break time='400ms'/> A battle between countries? <break time='400ms'/> A partnership or agreement to work together? <break time='400ms'/> or A border between nations? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! They agreed to protect EACH OTHER ‚Äî that's a cooperative partnership.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The verbose speaker went on for two hours, using far more words than necessary to make simple points.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does verbose mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Quiet? <break time='400ms'/> Nervous? <break time='400ms'/> Using too many words? <break time='400ms'/> or Funny? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Two hours and 'far more words than necessary' ‚Äî verbose means overly wordy!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The Latin root dict means "to say or speak." What does predict mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To say after? <break time='400ms'/> To say wrongly? <break time='400ms'/> To say before ‚Äî to tell what will happen in advance? <break time='400ms'/> or To say again? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Pre (before) + dict (say) = say before it happens = predict!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The Greek root graph means "to write." Which word means "a person's own handwriting of their name"?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Autograph? <break time='400ms'/> Telegraph? <break time='400ms'/> Geography? <break time='400ms'/> or Photograph? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Auto (self) + graph (write) = self-writing = your own signature!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The Latin root rupt means "to break." What does interrupt mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To speak quietly? <break time='400ms'/> To build something? <break time='400ms'/> To fix something broken? <break time='400ms'/> or To break into a conversation or process? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Inter (between) + rupt (break) = break into the middle of something.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The Greek prefix micro- means "small." What does microscope let you see?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very small things? <break time='400ms'/> Things in the dark? <break time='400ms'/> Things far away? <break time='400ms'/> or Very large things? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Micro (small) + scope (to view) = a tool for viewing small things!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>If bene- means good and mal- means bad, which word means "a person who does good"?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Malfunction? <break time='400ms'/> Benefactor? <break time='400ms'/> Malefactor? <break time='400ms'/> or Beneficial? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Bene (good) + factor (doer) = a person who does good (like donating money).</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A dictionary entry shows: "ar¬∑chi¬∑pel¬∑a¬∑go (ar-kuh-PEL-uh-go) n. a group of islands." What does the entry in parentheses tell you?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> How to pronounce the word? <break time='400ms'/> A synonym? <break time='400ms'/> When to use the word? <break time='400ms'/> or The word's origin? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The syllable breakdown and capitalized stress show you how to SAY the word.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>You want to find a word that means the same as happy but with a stronger feeling. Which reference should you use?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A thesaurus? <break time='400ms'/> An encyclopedia? <break time='400ms'/> A dictionary? <break time='400ms'/> or An atlas? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A thesaurus gives you synonyms ‚Äî words with similar meanings but different intensities.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In a dictionary, the abbreviation "v." means the word is a ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Very important word? <break time='400ms'/> Verb? <break time='400ms'/> Vowel? <break time='400ms'/> or Volume? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! v. = verb, n. = noun, adj. = adjective. These tell you the part of speech.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A dictionary shows three definitions for crane: 1. A large bird. 2. A machine for lifting heavy objects. 3. To stretch one's neck. The sentence is: "She craned her neck to see over the crowd." Which definition applies?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Definition 2? <break time='400ms'/> Definition 1? <break time='400ms'/> All three? <break time='400ms'/> or Definition 3? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! She stretched her neck to see ‚Äî that matches definition 3!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>When should you consult a reference material instead of relying only on context clues?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Never ‚Äî context clues are always sufficient? <break time='400ms'/> When context clues aren't enough to determine the precise meaning? <break time='400ms'/> Only during tests? <break time='400ms'/> or Always ‚Äî context clues never work? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Context clues are the first strategy, but sometimes you need the exact definition ‚Äî that's when you grab a dictionary.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The news hit her like a ton of bricks.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A metaphor? <break time='400ms'/> A simile? <break time='400ms'/> Personification? <break time='400ms'/> or An idiom? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The word 'like' compares the news to a ton of bricks. That's a simile!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The world is a stage, and we are merely players.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Onomatopoeia? <break time='400ms'/> Alliteration? <break time='400ms'/> A simile? <break time='400ms'/> or A metaphor? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It says the world IS a stage ‚Äî direct comparison without 'like' or 'as.' That's a metaphor.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the idiom "hit the nail on the head" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> To hammer something? <break time='400ms'/> To be exactly right? <break time='400ms'/> To build something? <break time='400ms'/> or To hurt yourself? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! If you hit a nail perfectly on its head, you got it exactly right!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The old car coughed and sputtered before finally dying on the side of the road.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This is an example of ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Personification? <break time='400ms'/> Simile? <break time='400ms'/> Alliteration? <break time='400ms'/> or Hyperbole? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Cars can't cough, sputter, or die ‚Äî those are human/living qualities given to a non-living thing.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which pair of words shows the GREATEST difference in intensity?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Big and large? <break time='400ms'/> Walk and stroll? <break time='400ms'/> Upset and furious? <break time='400ms'/> or Warm and hot? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Upset is mild. Furious is extreme. That's the biggest jump in intensity.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Her smile was as bright as the sun.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This simile compares ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> The sun to a lamp? <break time='400ms'/> Her teeth to stars? <break time='400ms'/> Her smile to the moon? <break time='400ms'/> or Her smile to sunlight ‚Äî both are bright and warm? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'As bright as the sun' ‚Äî her smile is being compared to the sun's brightness.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Time is money.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This metaphor means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Time is valuable and shouldn't be wasted, just like money? <break time='400ms'/> Clocks are expensive? <break time='400ms'/> Money takes time to earn? <break time='400ms'/> or You can buy time? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The metaphor says time IS money ‚Äî meaning time is just as valuable as money.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The dancer moved like water flowing over rocks.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>What quality of the dancer does this simile highlight?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> She was cold? <break time='400ms'/> She was fast? <break time='400ms'/> She moved smoothly and gracefully? <break time='400ms'/> or She was wet? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Water flowing over rocks is smooth and graceful ‚Äî that's how the dancer moved.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> He has a heart of stone.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>This metaphor means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> He needs a doctor? <break time='400ms'/> He collects rocks? <break time='400ms'/> He is very strong? <break time='400ms'/> or He is cold, uncaring, and unfeeling? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Stone is hard and cold. A heart of stone = a person who doesn't show emotions or compassion.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How do you tell the difference between a simile and a metaphor?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Similes use 'like' or 'as'; metaphors make a direct comparison without them? <break time='400ms'/> Similes are longer than metaphors? <break time='400ms'/> There is no difference? <break time='400ms'/> or Metaphors are always about animals? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Simile: 'brave AS a lion.' Metaphor: 'He IS a lion.' The words 'like/as' are the key difference.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the proverb "Don't judge a book by its cover" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Don't evaluate things or people based only on appearance? <break time='400ms'/> Book covers are ugly? <break time='400ms'/> Covers are important? <break time='400ms'/> or Always read the whole book? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A book (or person) might look one way on the outside but be completely different inside.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the adage "Actions speak louder than words" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Actions make noise? <break time='400ms'/> Talk loudly? <break time='400ms'/> What you DO matters more than what you SAY? <break time='400ms'/> or Words are quiet? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Anyone can SAY they'll help, but actually DOING it is what counts.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the idiom "costs an arm and a leg" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> It causes pain? <break time='400ms'/> You have to lose body parts? <break time='400ms'/> Something is very expensive? <break time='400ms'/> or It requires physical strength? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! You wouldn't literally give an arm and leg ‚Äî this means the price is extremely high!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the proverb "The early bird catches the worm" teach?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Worms are best in the morning? <break time='400ms'/> Those who act first or prepare early have an advantage? <break time='400ms'/> Birds wake up early? <break time='400ms'/> or Sleeping late is healthy? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Being early and taking action gives you an advantage ‚Äî in life, not just bird-feeding!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does "When it rains, it pours" mean?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Rain is always heavy? <break time='400ms'/> Always carry an umbrella? <break time='400ms'/> When problems happen, they tend to come all at once? <break time='400ms'/> or Pouring is worse than raining? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! It's not about weather ‚Äî it means difficulties tend to pile up all at the same time.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is a SYNONYM for courageous?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Brave? <break time='400ms'/> Cowardly? <break time='400ms'/> Weak? <break time='400ms'/> or Frightened? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A synonym has a similar meaning. Courageous and brave both mean showing courage.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is an ANTONYM for generous?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Kind? <break time='400ms'/> Wealthy? <break time='400ms'/> Giving? <break time='400ms'/> or Selfish? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An antonym is the opposite. The opposite of giving freely (generous) is keeping everything for yourself (selfish).</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The words happy, "joyful," and ecstatic are synonyms, but they differ in ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> They mean completely different things? <break time='400ms'/> Nothing ‚Äî they're identical? <break time='400ms'/> Their spelling? <break time='400ms'/> or Their intensity ‚Äî from mild to extreme happiness? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Happy is mild. Joyful is stronger. Ecstatic is extreme. Same family, different levels.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Which word BEST replaces said to show the character is angry?<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"'That's not fair!" ____ Marcus."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Whispered? <break time='400ms'/> Sighed? <break time='400ms'/> Mumbled? <break time='400ms'/> or Shouted? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! An angry person saying 'That's not fair!' would most likely raise their voice ‚Äî shout!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which pair are antonyms?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Ancient and old? <break time='400ms'/> Quick and fast? <break time='400ms'/> Brave and courageous? <break time='400ms'/> or Expand and contract? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Expand = get bigger. Contract = get smaller. Those are opposites!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which sentence uses the most precise language?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Something moved quickly up there.? <break time='400ms'/> It went really, really fast.? <break time='400ms'/> The rocket accelerated through the atmosphere at tremendous speed.? <break time='400ms'/> or The thing went fast.? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Precise means specific. 'Rocket,' 'accelerated,' 'atmosphere,' and 'tremendous' are all precise.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In social studies, the word democracy means ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> A system where citizens have the power to make decisions through voting? <break time='400ms'/> A military government? <break time='400ms'/> A type of economy? <break time='400ms'/> or Rule by one king? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Demo = people. Cracy = rule. Democracy = rule by the people.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Replace nice with a more precise word:.<break time='400ms'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The ____ sunset painted the sky in shades of orange and pink."</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Good? <break time='400ms'/> Nice? <break time='400ms'/> Spectacular? <break time='400ms'/> or Okay? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A sunset that paints the sky deserves a more vivid word than 'nice'!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The academic phrase in contrast signals that the author is about to ‚Äî</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Give an example? <break time='400ms'/> Show a difference? <break time='400ms'/> Summarize? <break time='400ms'/> or Conclude? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! 'In contrast' = the next idea will be different from the previous one.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word BEST describes someone who stammered, looked at the floor, and spoke in a shaky voice?</emphasis><break time='400ms'/> Excited? <break time='400ms'/> Nervous? <break time='400ms'/> Bored? <break time='400ms'/> or Confident? <break time='400ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Stammering, avoiding eye contact, shaky voice ‚Äî classic signs of nervousness!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:
